story:
Short and Sweet

Hi, I’m Lauren – an artist, art teacher, and photographer. I have the amazing opportunity to study printmaking in India with Lotta Jansdotter. Traveling to India is something I have always dreamed of doing, so when I heard about this trip I knew it was the right time! This adventure will allow me to be fully immersed in the practice of making art - creating a new body of photographic work inspired by the colors of India and also learning a new skill that will help me grow as an artist and art educator. With your contributions I will get to explore a new country, build my portfolio, and bring back what I have learned to share with my community.  

 

Here is a link with the trip details:

http://ritchieacecamps.com/lotta-jansdotter/

 

How much will it cost?

I will spend 8 days in Jaipur – The Pink City – located in Northern India. Jaipur is a bustling city known for its beautiful artwork and textiles. During the 8 days, I will tour museums and artists’ studios, participate in a printmaking workshop led by artist, Lotta Jansdotter, shop the colorful bazaars, eat amazing food, and soak in all of the sites this creative city has to offer.

 

The total cost of the trip and art show afterward will be close to $5,000.

$3,149 – Ace Camp – includes accommodations (8 nights), food, transportation in India, museum admissions, and the 3 day workshop with Lotta.

$1,000 – Round trip airfare to New Delhi – with a 17 hour layover in London, England!

$40 – Round trip train fare from New Delhi to Jaipur.

$100 or more – Miscellaneous (bus/taxi) travel expenses in New Delhi, Jaipur, and London.

$100 or more – Food outside of the workshop


The rest of the funds will go toward buying supplies to print on during the workshop, fulfilling the perks listed here, and having a solo exhibition at Two-Thirds Studio in early 2014.

www.twothirdsstudio.com

 

What do you get in return?

I have created a list of perks as thank you gifts for your financial contributions. It was lot of fun thinking of how I could give back to those who help me reach my goal. Some of the perks give you options - send me a note when you contribute to let me know what you would like. Check them out and thank you for considering funding my project!

When I visit a new place one of my goals as a photographer is to represent my surroundings in a light that reflects my personality. The images I create are often simple, colorful, and modern. Through photography I strive to make connections between places I visit, allowing the images to speak to each other.

As a crafter and sewer, I have always been interested in creating a product that is similar to my photography: simple, colorful, and modern. After learning the techniques offered in the workshop it is my goal to design and create beautiful fabrics that I will sew into circle scarves. For some time now I have been trying to come up with a product that would represent me as an artist and appeal to the consumer - I think this is it!!!! (I’m really excited about it…can you tell?)

Check out my newest work here:

http://msditchley.tumblr.com/

 

The Impact

As a person – This experience will broaden my view of the world.

As an artist and teacher – I will share this view to foster cross-cultural connections.

 

Other Ways to Help

Help me spread the word about my campaign!

You can share right from Indiegogo by clicking the tab to your favorite social media outlet! 

 

Thank you for your support!
story_txt:
Short and Sweet
Hi, I’m Lauren – an artist, art teacher, and photographer. I have the amazing opportunity to study printmaking in India with Lotta Jansdotter. Traveling to India is something I have always dreamed of doing, so when I heard about this trip I knew it was the right time! This adventure will allow me to be fully immersed in the practice of making art - creating a new body of photographic work inspired by the colors of India and also learning a new skill that will help me grow as an artist and art educator. With your contributions I will get to explore a new country, build my portfolio, and bring back what I have learned to share with my community.  
 
Here is a link with the trip details:
http://ritchieacecamps.com/lotta-jansdotter/
 
How much will it cost?


I will spend 8 days in Jaipur – The Pink City – located in Northern India. Jaipur is a bustling city known for its beautiful artwork and textiles. During the 8 days, I will tour museums and artists’ studios, participate in a printmaking workshop led by artist, Lotta Jansdotter, shop the colorful bazaars, eat amazing food, and soak in all of the sites this creative city has to offer.
 
The total cost of the trip and art show afterward will be close to $5,000.
$3,149 – Ace Camp – includes accommodations (8 nights), food, transportation in India, museum admissions, and the 3 day workshop with Lotta.
$1,000 – Round trip airfare to New Delhi – with a 17 hour layover in London, England!
$40 – Round trip train fare from New Delhi to Jaipur.
$100 or more – Miscellaneous (bus/taxi) travel expenses in New Delhi, Jaipur, and London.
$100 or more – Food outside of the workshop
The rest of the funds will go toward buying supplies to print on during the workshop, fulfilling the perks listed here, and having a solo exhibition at Two-Thirds Studio in early 2014.
www.twothirdsstudio.com
 

What do you get in return?
I have created a list of perks as thank you gifts for your financial contributions. It was lot of fun thinking of how I could give back to those who help me reach my goal. Some of the perks give you options - send me a note when you contribute to let me know what you would like. Check them out and thank you for considering funding my project!

When I visit a new place one of my goals as a photographer is to represent my surroundings in a light that reflects my personality. The images I create are often simple, colorful, and modern. Through photography I strive to make connections between places I visit, allowing the images to speak to each other.

As a crafter and sewer, I have always been interested in creating a product that is similar to my photography: simple, colorful, and modern. After learning the techniques offered in the workshop it is my goal to design and create beautiful fabrics that I will sew into circle scarves. For some time now I have been trying to come up with a product that would represent me as an artist and appeal to the consumer - I think this is it!!!! (I’m really excited about it…can you tell?)

Check out my newest work here:
http://msditchley.tumblr.com/
 
The Impact
As a person – This experience will broaden my view of the world.
As an artist and teacher – I will share this view to foster cross-cultural connections.
 
Other Ways to Help
Help me spread the word about my campaign!
You can share right from Indiegogo by clicking the tab to your favorite social media outlet! 
 
Thank you for your support!

story:
Quien soy?

Mi nombre es Olaff  Ramos, Artista plástico y padre de dos hermosos hijos, Akira y Aoki, uno de 5 años y otro de 9 meses, siempre dando gracias  a Dios por darme la oportunidad de compartir mi vida al lado de una mujer inteligente y  hermosa, Joy, Somos Venezolanos, hace tiempo ya radicados aquí en Bogotá – Colombia.

Un proyecto mas alla del arte!

 

Actualmente me encuentro trabajando en una exposición de arte programada para el día 22 de Agosto del presente año denominada “PUSH-FIT inspirado en los primeros rompecabezas del siglo XX , ese juego de “colocar  y  empujar”, pero  desde la sutileza erótica que nos transporta a espacios temporales  improvisados y creativos, bajo reglas y acciones que bajo un común acuerdo,  nos permite participar o no, he allí la magia de la sensualidad y el erotismo, la libertad de elegir si aceptamos o no ser parte del juego.

Los visitantes a la exposición Push-fit, podrán interactuar con obras de arte tales como pinturas, instalaciones, esculturas y grabados, llevándolos  a fluctuar desde otros campos a un juego de seducción poética.

Regalemos días de felicidad en sus corazones!

Con toda la honestidad del caso, la recaudación de vuestra colaboración tendrán dos  beneficiarios finales, uno será destinado a culminar gran parte  de 47 piezas de arte, entre pinturas , esculturas y grabados el 70%  y el otro 30% para una fundación que acoge a más de 12 niños  con cáncer que son abandonados a su suerte, se llama “Fundación Alegría” con la cual estamos trabajando junto a mi familia y amigos, colaborando en lo básico, pero lo más importante llevándoles cada vez que  podemos, una luz de esperanza, a través de juegos y el compartir con ellos.

Lo que necesitamos y lo que obtienes!

Por cada 1200 $ te harás acreedor de una pieza de arte autenticada y original (grabado) de la serie terciopelo, y siempre te será dado percibir la gratitud del alma por ayudar a estos niños ...

Otras formas en las que puedes ayudar
Difunde la campaña y usa las herramientas de compartir de Indiegogo

story:
HAPPY HALF BIRTHDAY!!! THE CONSORTIUM IS 4 1/2!!!  

Arizona Consortium for the Arts is a 501c3 tax exempt organization dedicated to fostering and supporting the arts and artists encompassing all disciplines,   including the literary arts (writers, poets, and playwrights), the visual arts (any form â€” painters, sculptors, muralists) and the performing arts (music, plays, performance art).   To learn more about us please visit our website at www.artizona.org.

IT'S TIME TO PUT ON OUR BIG BOY PANTS

IT'S TIME FOR OUR BIG PUSH!!!  Arizona Consortium for the Arts is preparing for its first annual fundraising brunch in 2012-2013, and there are many basic things we need to make it a success!!!

The Consortium needs a HD Camcorder to document its festivals as well as prepare commercial advertisement for the 2012-2013 brunch.  Since Santa didn't bring it for Christmas this year, we are looking for your help!!!

Your donations help us in our continual operational growth to serve community members and underprivileged areas through free art outreach events.


OUR HALF BIRTHDAY PRESENT

For the Consortium's half birthday, we would love the CANNON VIXIA HG21.  However, unlike the kids on MTV's My Super Sweet 16, we aren't asking just one person for it.  Instead we would love if our friends all pitched in to get us the camcorder of our dreams!!!

And for those of you who like The Price is Right, the retail value of the cam corder is $1,199

Any additional funds raised will go towards our 4th Annual Blue Guitar Festival of the Arts coming up in March.


BEST FRIENDS TEXT ABOUT THEIR BEST FRIENDS

Gossip about us! PLEASE!  We BEG you!  Tell everyone about what the Consortium does for the community, and what we want for our half birthday.

In return, we promise to gossip about you in our social media and marketing.  Collaboration is key to all of our survival.

story:
Take a moment and allow yourself to dream; imagine if you heard that a carnival was setting up for only one night in an abandoned lot just outside of town. Skeptically, you arrive, not sure what to expect, but knowing it is not to be missed. As you get closer, you can see the glow of fire reaching up through the darkness. Suddenly, an explosion of sparks arises with a boisterous roar of engines and cheering from the crowd. Eager to get inside you run to the entrance, and despite the warning “BEWARE OF CLOWNS” you surrender all the cash in your pocket to the majestic beauty in the booth, who in exchange hands you a token.

Inside, your senses are overwhelmed. The smell of cotton candy,popcorn, and lingering propane is somehow comforting among the fire lit midway as various contraptions erupt with sparks and fire. You decide to take your chances at a game of darts, and let the fortune teller decipher your prophecy.

At the stroke of midnight, fire starts to rise from the dark end of the lot illuminating a stage. A band starts to play a familiar yet disturbing lullaby as brightly clad performers crawl into the light. Let the show begin...  

Ladies and gentlemen;

STEP RIGHT UP! THE CIRCUS IS COMING TO TOWN!

Introducing the newest addition to Seattle’s enchanting underground entertainment; our very own Circus of Industry!

The Circus of Industry (COI) is not only creating an evolving spectacle of music, fire, and performance, but an interactive full-scale carnival midway complete with games, concessions, freaks, and curiosities. COI has defined this greater realm as “The Carnival of Bad Decisions”.

COI is preparing a special Benefit show for February 16th in Seattle, in which we will premiere some of our original, one-of-a-kind instruments that manipulate fire and logic. Entertainment throughout the evening will be provided by our contributing performers and friends of COI. We invite you to join us, not only to experience the birth of the Circus of Industry, but to help support the growth of our full scale production. Advanced Tickets to this event can be obtained by contributing to our Indiegogo campaign.

This initial $2,500 through Indiegogo will help offset the costs of building the Circus of Industry and The Carnival of Bad Decisions. Your contribution will go directly towards construction materials and supplies, including: lumber, steel, paint, lights, and of course... PROPANE! To make our vision possible over the next 5 years, our total fundraising goal through grants, sponsorship, and donations is $100,000. We will achieve this goal only with the help of those who still believe that a circus can change the world.

Your contribution of at least $20 will get you 1 standard admission ticket to our Preview Benefit. For a donation of at least $50, you will receive 1 VIC (Very Important Carney) ticket to our Preview Benefit, a COI keepsake, and official recognition as a sponsor.

With your help, we can continue to build in a sustainable, modular fashion, so our production can be easily transported to festivals and events around the globe. We feel strongly that in times like these, participating in fun events such as the Circus is becoming more important. Please consider making a donation to the Circus of Industry and help support the underground circus merrymakers of Seattle.

The Circus of Industry was founded in 2012 by Sam Scharf, David Stern, and Madisun Avenue, whose combined performance experiences range from radical noise ensembles, street theater, marching bands, and heavy metal to musical theater and dance. Behind the scenes, skills of the producers and crew vary between metal fabrication, blacksmithing, carpentry, costume design, lighting and sound design, music production, choreography, fire safety, and more.

The Circus of Industry is bringing together Seattle's most creative and skillful individuals to create something truly unique, with the sole purpose of entertainment. An interactive spectacle of fire, music, clowns, and freaks! We hope you will join us on this journey.

Thank you.

Making Bad Decisions since 2012,
The Circus of Industry

Past successfully funded projects from the producers of Circus of Industry include:
HONK! Fest West (www.HonkfestWest.com)
Titanium Sporkestra - Tours: 2010, 2011, 2012
Passion, or Death!

story:
“There is no greater agony than bearing an untold story inside you.”

 ― Maya Angelou

Artists' Books for Social Change

Jarring is a project by artist Mirabelle Jones to create a set of letterpress & digitally printed artists' books that end the silence and stigma surrounding sexual assault and rape by sharing the real life experiences of 22 survivors. The goal of this project is to create a publicly accessible archive of survivor narratives while raising funds for Rape Crisis Centers (RCCs) through book sales. Any funds received which are in excess of this project's goal amount will be turned into donations for Rape Crisis Centers as well as any profits from book sales.

Ending the Stigma & Silence Surrounding Sexual Assault

In 2011, I began a project entitled JARRING with the idea of working with survivors of sexual assault and rape to publicly share their experiences. Despite the pervasiveness of rape and sexual assault in our society, affecting one in six women and one in thirty two men, survivors are shamed from speaking out about their experiences. Once I began speaking out, others came to me with their stories. The more I listened, the more I felt very strongly that these stories needed a place where they could be honored and serve as a platform for discussion about sexual assault and rape in our communities.

I started by breaking the stories down into three parts and storing them in three colored jars to mark the three stages of each experience: the green jar held the beginning of each person's experience. The red jar stored words and phrases concerning the assault. The blue contained each survivor's personal reflections on the experience at the time they submitted their story. The stories began to build, the jars taking on their own symbolic meaning as containers of a complex and socially repressed discourse.

Artists' Books for Social Change

In 2013, I decided to create a limited edition, hand-made digitally & letterpress printed set of books based on JARRING with the goal of creating a publicly accessible archive that would truly honor these stories, building a bridge between private and public discourse. The project entails making three books, one for each jar or part of the story, in a set of 50. Each book utilizes a different book structure to create a unique experience that honors the text and experiences represented while using the artwork and structure of the book to tell a story embedded in form, imagery, and movement as well as language. 

Book one is a letterpress printed, accordion format book printed in an edition of 50 printed during a residency at Women's Studio Workshop in Rosendale, NY. I chose 11 handset type faces from the studio to signify the different voices and produced a photo-polymer plate of the original jar to serve as the main artwork. Additionally, the book will be laser cut to give the illusion of slips of paper in a translucent container. 

Book two uses the flag book structure where slips of paper jut across each other to create the impression of multiple, layered voices. The book will be made of contrasting red acrylic and artist's papers, digitally printed with textures and text.

Book three will be a sculptural codex made of layers of Thai artist's papers, block printed and hand bound with wax thread.

The three books will be stored together in a slip case and sold to private collectors as well as some special collections libraries, creating a freely accessible archive of these narratives in one of the places they are most needed: the college campus. All profits from book sales as well as any amount I receive in this campaign which exceeds costs will go towards donations for RCCs. The project has the potential to raise over $20,000 for crisis centers through book sales and this fundraiser. It is my goal that for every book sold, I will offer one handling copy to a crisis center for therapeutic and personal use by survivors.

Where Your Funds Go

I am grateful to have received a project assistance grant from the College Book Arts Association, but am still in need of funding for the remainder of the project's costs. In exchange, I'm excited to offer you a number of limited edition letterpress prints and other artful items to reward and inspire you. Any funds raised through this campaign in excess of the amount needed to finish the project will go towards donations for RCCs**, so consider this an opportunity to receive a handmade work of art for your donation to a good cause!

What You Get for Your Contribution

In exchange for contributing to this project, you can select from a number of prints I've done over the years or specifically for this project. Examples below!


Special Thanks To: Women's Studio Workshop, The College Book Arts Association, Bay Area Women Against Rape, RAINN.org, Mills College Book Arts, Pandora's Aquarium, the crisis centers throughout the country which have spread the word about the project to date, and to the 22 survivors who were brave enough to share their story for this project.

You can read more about the project on the artist's website at: http://www.mirabellejones.com/jarring-a-book-arts-campaign-for-social-change/

Q & A

Why Share Stories of Sexual Assault?
I believe strongly that every narrative deserves a place for discussion in our community. This is especially important in regards to narratives which we find difficult to tell, and those which are difficult to hear. These narratives are integral to our understanding and acknowledgement of one of the most complex and destructive issues we face in society. By launching this project, it is my goal to encourage dialogue, unite the voices of survivors, dispel many of the myths related to sexual assault and rape by confronting them with true experiences, raise funds for RCCs through book sales and donations, and create an archive that is accessible to the public for research as well as for personal therapeutic use.

What Are the Funds Needed For?
In addition to the material costs, which for a set of three hand-made books (including one letterpress book) in an edition of 50 are pretty overwhelming, I've also been paying for any associated costs (including residency costs, travel costs, and letterpress access) out of pocket. I have not factored in any costs associated with my own labor as I am not paying myself for my time. Your donations specifically will go towards material costs, travel costs, residency costs, and shipping costs necessary for the completion and placement of the books. 

What Is An RCC? Why Support RCCs?
Rape Crisis Centers (RCCs) provide vital services to survivors of sexual assault and rape that are absolutely crucial. These services may include offering counseling services, operating hotlines, community outreach & education, accompanying victims to the police station or hospital, helping survivors to make and pursue police reports, arranging legal or medical services, arranging victim's compensation for psychiatric services, and much more. Many RCCs are staffed primarily by volunteers and all are greatly assisted by public donations. Your contribution ensures they can continue to provide these necessary services.

Why Don't I Just Donate to the RCC Directly?
Considering the difference in costs and book sales, this project has the potential to raise over $20,000 for RCCs. Any donations I receive in excess of what I need to complete this project will also go towards donations to RCCs AND you'll get an artwork perk for your donation. So this way, you get something great for your donation and get to be part of a larger campaign with a potentially bigger payoff.

Why Is the Book So Expensive?
Unlike commercially produced books, self-published artist's books are extremely time consuming and costly to make. While I could have produced a more inexpensive, commercially accessible version of Jarring, I decided to create this set of limited edition artist's books using high quality materials with the intention of both honoring the narratives and creating work which is archival and built to last. I've tried to make the reward of the books as inexpensive as possible, but in order to support my goal of donating 1 handling copy to an RCC for every copy sold, I can't make it any less without the fundraising goal of the project losing strength. Update: I have added a perk of an economically priced, digitally printed codex set for private collections should you wish to have a version of the books for yourself or your organization.

How Else Can I Help?

If you are an artist and would like to run a similar campaign for a local crisis center, you can become a part of Art Against Assault. Campaigns can include performances, installations, or donations from artwork sales. Please visit the Art Against Assault website for more info.: ArtAgainstAssault.com

If you are a college student, you can talk to your special collections librarian about purchasing a copy of JARRING for your campus. Copies can be pre-ordered through this campaign or can be requested by email.

If you are interested in Art Against Assault, you can follow us on our Facebook page or Twitter to learn of upcoming events and campaigns in your area.

If you are a journalist or blogger you can share this campaign with your readers! Thank you!

*Statistics from Rainn.org. Note: statistics only reflect reported incidents and it is estimate that approx 60% of assaults go unreported. **All donations received which are in excess of this project's necessary funding or the goal amount (whichever is less) will be turned into donations for Rape Crisis Centers. This excludes Indiegogo's campaign fees which are 4% of the total and 3% for credit card processing, as well as any funds needed to make & ship rewards. If you would like to recommend an RCC for your donation, you can do so in the comments! Thank you!

It is my goal that for every book sold, I will offer one handling copy to a crisis center for therapeutic and personal use by survivors. Where Your Funds Go
I am grateful to have received a project assistance grant from the College Book Arts Association, but am still in need of funding for the remainder of the project's costs. In exchange, I'm excited to offer you a number of limited edition letterpress prints and other artful items to reward and inspire you. Any funds raised through this campaign in excess of the amount needed to finish the project will go towards donations for RCCs**, so consider this an opportunity to receive a handmade work of art for your donation to a good cause! What You Get for Your ContributionIn exchange for contributing to this project, you can select from a number of prints I've done over the years or specifically for this project. Examples below!Special Thanks To: Women's Studio Workshop, The College Book Arts Association, Bay Area Women Against Rape, RAINN.org, Mills College Book Arts, Pandora's Aquarium, the crisis centers throughout the country which have spread the word about the project to date, and to the 22 survivors who were brave enough to share their story for this project. You can read more about the project on the artist's website at: http://www.mirabellejones.com/jarring-a-book-arts-campaign-for-social-change/Q & A
Why Share Stories of Sexual Assault?I believe strongly that every narrative deserves a place for discussion in our community. This is especially important in regards to narratives which we find difficult to tell, and those which are difficult to hear. These narratives are integral to our understanding and acknowledgement of one of the most complex and destructive issues we face in society. By launching this project, it is my goal to encourage dialogue, unite the voices of survivors, dispel many of the myths related to sexual assault and rape by confronting them with true experiences, raise funds for RCCs through book sales and donations, and create an archive that is accessible to the public for research as well as for personal therapeutic use. What Are the Funds Needed For?In addition to the material costs, which for a set of three hand-made books (including one letterpress book) in an edition of 50 are pretty overwhelming, I've also been paying for any associated costs (including residency costs, travel costs, and letterpress access) out of pocket. I have not factored in any costs associated with my own labor as I am not paying myself for my time. Your donations specifically will go towards material costs, travel costs, residency costs, and shipping costs necessary for the completion and placement of the books. What Is An RCC? Why Support RCCs?Rape Crisis Centers (RCCs) provide vital services to survivors of sexual assault and rape that are absolutely crucial. These services may include offering counseling services, operating hotlines, community outreach & education, accompanying victims to the police station or hospital, helping survivors to make and pursue police reports, arranging legal or medical services, arranging victim's compensation for psychiatric services, and much more. Many RCCs are staffed primarily by volunteers and all are greatly assisted by public donations. Your contribution ensures they can continue to provide these necessary services. Why Don't I Just Donate to the RCC Directly?Considering the difference in costs and book sales, this project has the potential to raise over $20,000 for RCCs. Any donations I receive in excess of what I need to complete this project will also go towards donations to RCCs AND you'll get an artwork perk for your donation. So this way, you get something great for your donation and get to be part of a larger campaign with a potentially bigger payoff.Why Is the Book So Expensive?Unlike commercially produced 
books, self-published artist's books are extremely time 
consuming and costly to make. While I could have produced a more
 inexpensive, commercially accessible version of Jarring, I decided to 
create this set of limited edition artist's books using high quality materials with the intention of 
both honoring the narratives and creating work which is archival and built to last. I've tried to make the reward of the books as inexpensive
 as possible, but in order to support my goal of donating 1 handling copy to an 
RCC for every copy sold, I can't make it any less without the fundraising goal of the project losing strength. Update: I have added a perk of an economically priced, digitally printed codex set for private collections should you wish to have a version of the books for yourself or your organization. How Else Can I Help?If you are an artist and would like to run a similar campaign for a local crisis center, you can become a part of Art Against Assault. Campaigns can include performances, installations, or donations from artwork sales. Please visit the Art Against Assault website for more info.: ArtAgainstAssault.comIf you are a college student, you can talk to your special collections librarian about purchasing a copy of JARRING for your campus. Copies can be pre-ordered through this campaign or can be requested by email. If you are interested in Art Against Assault, you can follow us on our Facebook page or Twitter to learn of upcoming events and campaigns in your area.If you are a journalist or blogger you can share this campaign with your readers! Thank you!*Statistics from Rainn.org. Note: statistics only reflect reported incidents and it is estimate that approx 60% of assaults go unreported. **All
 donations received which are in excess of this project's necessary 
funding or the goal amount (whichever is less) will be turned into 
donations for Rape Crisis Centers. This excludes Indiegogo's campaign 
fees which are 4% of the total and 3% for credit card processing, as 
well as any funds needed to make & ship rewards. If you would like 
to recommend an RCC for your donation, you can do so in the comments! 
Thank you!

story:
Short Summary

The goal is to get a picture of 1 million dollars, nothing more.

What We Need & What You Get

We need 1 million dollars, you can get prints, a t-shirt, a mug and many limited items with the picture of a million dollars on it.. A million dollars is a large amount of money, and it would be a feat to fit this all into one picture.

Risks & Challenges

This project is virtually risk free, seeing as the money will be in a safe account until the picture is taken. Once the picture has been taken, a large portion will be donated to a charity chosen by the top investor.

And that's all there is to it.

story:
We Are Artistspotter

At Artistspotter, we spot visual artists in various countries around the world and bridge them with interested buyers. 

  • We focus on contemporary photographers, painters, sculptors, designers, and illustrators from around the world.
  • We sell only original artwork. We guarantee authenticity as your artwork is shipped directly from the artist's studio.
  • Our artists can also create unique, custom-made artwork to complete the décor of your home or business environment.

Why We Are Raising Funds

Your contribution will: 

  • Help us get Artistspotter live online, by covering a portion of our website IT development costs. The website will go live early 2014. 
  • Help our artists get discovered and connected with interested buyer-collectors, by supporting a portion of our upcoming silent auction. The silent auction will be held in New York City to celebrate the website launch.

How You Can Contribute

There is no small contribution!
Any unclaimed perks will be distributed among contributors at the end of the campaign.

  • Donate a pre-set amount and receive one of the many perks listed on the right-hand side of this campaign page.
  • Simply click on "contribute now" to donate your preferred amount. 
  • Unable to donate? Help us get the word out and tell the world about our campaign and upcoming launch. Share this campaign link on Facebook! Tell your friends!

You Will Have a Global Impact

Support 25+ artists from 10+ countries on 3 continents (and growing!).

Featured countries and artists include: Australia (Dale Rhodes),  Hungary (Attila Bartis), France (Magdalena Torma), Netherlands (Jacques Tange), Peru/US (Coco Martin), Spain (Lisa Temes), Romania (Cosmin Bumbut, Bogdan Croitoru, Boldiszar Deak, Hajdu Tamas, Adrian Podolean), UK/US (Saroj Patel), US (Barry Grose, Rosanna Scimeca, Vivianne Nantel), and more. Click here for a full list.

All funds raised will be used for the website development and launch and for our upcoming silent auction. This project it is set to go live approximately 2.5 months after the end of this crowdfunding campaign. Have more questions? E-mail us at: info@artistspotter.com.

What You Receive For Your Contribution

Below are all the gifts that our gracious donors can receive in exchange for their contribution. All of the artworks have been donated by Artistspotter artists. View additional details on the right-hand side of the campaign page.

story:
the Love Letters Project

Since February of 2013 I have been typing love letters, making 100 copies and anonymously inserting them in the SF weekly on Wednesday. Some of the letters have been previously written at some point in history. 

Taken from poetry, lyrics, famous people, made up by me. 

The letters are intense, some are funny, desperate, all mixed with emotions, full of typos, imperfect.

The motivation to do this was in a sense to bring love back. Love Letters is inspired by conceptual and installation art. I wanted to set up an intimate experience for a stranger. Inserting the letters in the SF weekly was an easy and effective way of getting them out in the city. It allowed anyone that picked up the paper the chance to discover a letter. I do not give any indication of who wrote the letter or what the letter is intended for. My objective is for the person to have their own individual experience without interference or self-promotion. 


the Love Letters Book & Exhibit


In February 2014 (1 year anniversary of the project) all of the letters will framed and exhibited in Adobe Bookstore located in the Mission District of San Francisco, California. On February 14th, 2014 (Valentine's Day) I will have an event at Adobe. This will be an exhibition and a book release party for Love letters. I am raising money so that I afford to print the book in time for the event.


What am I raising money for...


I will be printing 250 books for the exhibition Love Letters at 1984 Printing in Oakland. The cost of printing is $1060.

$900 for a 64 page book

$160 for a full color cover

All the money I raise will go to the cost of printing the book.


Why contribute? What's the impact?

By supporting this project you are supporting the creation of a book from this year long project, Love letters. 

It is a conscious decision to bring my project to 1984 printing. They are a small printing company run by two women in Oakland. By contributing to this campaign, not only are you supporting my project you are also supporting small business owners. 

The exhibit will take place at Adobe books. Adobe has a long history in San Francisco and have supported the work of local artists for 25 years. Last year the land lord raised their rent and they were evicted. Luckily they were able to do an indiegogo campaign of their own to relocate. www.indiegogo.com/projects/save-adobe-books/x/478038. By supporting this project you are also supporting the success of events at Adobe Books. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the love. If anyone you know might be interested in this project please send them the link or feel free to post it on Facebook! xoxoxo

Promote the show in February at Adobe! Even better...Come check it out!!!

story:
Gulf Labor needs your help self-publishing a report about the conditions of Abu Dhabi’s migrant workers who are building branches of the Guggenheim and the Louvre.

The gleaming cityscapes of Abu Dhabi and Dubai are being assembled, at boomtown speed, from the hard-pressed labor of armies of migrant workers from India, Bangladesh, Pakistan, and Nepal. Bound to an employer by the kafala sponsorship system, the laborers arrive, heavily indebted from recruitment and transit fees, only to find that their Gulf Dream has been a mirage. Typically, the sponsoring employer takes their passports, houses them in substandard labor camps, pays much less than they were promised, and enforces a punishing work regimen under the hot desert sun. Many fall prey to suicide, or die from overwork or overheat.

For the past three years, Gulf Labor, a coalition of artists and writers, has been working on achieving fairer labor standards for the workers by pressuring the museums constructing branches on the new cultural zone on Abu Dhabi’s Saadiyat Island. More than two thousand members of the international artworld have joined our boycott of the Guggenheim Abu Dhabi, scheduled to ramp up construction this year. Gulf Labor has taken a hard line in negotiations with the museum and UAE authorities, organized the 52 Weeks agit-prop campaign, and staged four spectacular occupations of the Guggenheim New York. In his roundup of 2014's notable events,  the New York Times art critic, Holland Cotter, singled out the Gulf Labor campaign and the work of Global Ultra Luxury Faction (its direct action spinoff). “The groups’ action,” he summarized, “has been carefully organized, effectively executed and persistent, as any protest that’s going to work must be.”

Last year, a Gulf Labor team visited labor camps and produced a preliminary report, which has been used and cited by Human Rights Watch, Amnesty International, the International Trade Union Congress, and other NGOs active in the Gulf states.  To combat the lavish propaganda about Saadiyat Island spun by the Abu Dhabi authorities, we need to return to the camps to gather more testimony and update the findings. We hope to undertake two trips this spring, and release a new report in the summer.

No one should be asked to visit, exhibit or perform in a museum built on the backs of abused workers.

Funding will cover the following:

  1. Two week-long research trips undertaken by small GL teams. Field interviews will be conducted with workers in Abu Dhabi labor camps.

  2. Self-publication of the report.

  3.  Distribution of the report and a newsprint pamphlet to workers and worker organizations in the UAE, India, Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Nepal

story:
Hi I'm Brendan, I'm a 24 year old artist living in Provincetown, Massachusetts. It has always been a dream of mine to produce artwork for a living, I think that can be said of most artists. Along with that dream though, I've got many more artistic dreams such as learning animation, starting a comic series, becoming a sign maker, the list goes on. The sorts of projects I'm truly passionate about and would love to explore are nowadays, mostly digital. Most digital artistic endeavors boil down to a few simple tools, but none more vital than a computer. Specifically one that can stand up to whatever challenges the artist has to throw at it. I'm hoping to upgrade my creative arsenal in a big way, as I'm currently confined to only traditional mediums. Although traditional mediums are fantastic, they don't lend themselves to being easily shared with the entire world via the internet. I have many projects lined up to work on this winter (after all, there's not much else to do off-season on Cape Cod) and in order to pursue these projects, I'm going to need a computer with some serious power....because my three year old laptop that I use for pretty much everything has started to kick the bucket and can barely handle email at this point, let alone any programs needed to produce digital artwork.

That's where you come in. With your help I'm hoping to raise enough money to buy a computer with some serious processing power so that I can learn some new things, create some great work and at some point make a living off of it. This is just the catalyst for hoping to complete a lifelong dream and YOU could contribute to it! I've got some great perks for those who donate and every little bit helps, really, any donations are appreciated.

I priced out what I would need for a custom computer fit with all the hardware I need to accomplish the projects I have in mind, and the price of that computer is the goal I'm hoping to reach. With it being a custom computer, if I don't reach the goal, I can always swap out components, so all money donated is still going toward furthering my artistic accomplishments. Once I've got the computer, I plan on opening commissions, starting a Patreon account and releasing all sorts of material like webcomics, illustrated podcasts and eventually, somewhere down the line, an animated webseries. With these goals in mind, I'll hopefully also accomplish my dream of making a living off of my artwork!

I hope you'll help me open up a new chapter in my life and please donate or share this with friends or other patrons of the arts in order to reach this goal! Thanks for reading!

~Brendan

If you'd like to see some samples of my day to day artwork feel free to check me out on Instagram: @bleat09

I've also provided links below to my Facebook and Tumblr pages if you'd like to see past projects that have been completed.

Once I've got the computer, I plan on opening commissions, starting a Patreon account and releasing all sorts of material like webcomics, illustrated podcasts and eventually, somewhere down the line, an animated webseries. Thanks for reading!~BrendanIf you'd like to see some samples of my day to day artwork feel free to check me out on Instagram: @bleat09I've also provided links below to my Facebook and Tumblr pages if you'd like to see past projects that have been completed.

story:
Amazing! We've exceeded our goal - so we've decided to aim even higher. Follow this link for our new fundraising page: http://bit.ly/1vFMY8s



Short Summary

On March 1st 2015, Charlie Warner and Geordie Palmer have decided to take a break from their 4th year degrees/soup making and run the Bath Half Marathon for a wonderful cause- The Lalela Project. 

The Lalela Project is very close to Charlie who, whilst growing up spending lots of time with family in Cape Town, has been fortunate enough to work for this fantastic charity which provides educational arts to youth affected by extreme poverty in order to spark creative thinking and awaken entrepreneurial spirit.

Please feel free to learn more about The Lalela Project here: http://www.lalelaproject.org

What We Need & What You Get

Whatever you kind people are willing to give help us get over the finish line!

In doing so, you will be helping thousands of young people to become inspired by the powerful universal language of Art.

100% of the funds raised will be going to the Lalela Project.

The Impact: More About Lalela Project

Lalela Project provides art-risk youth with innovative arts education to spark creative thinking and awaken the entrepreneurial spirit! Lalela believes in the power of arts education to empower students to map and manifest a better future for themselves and their communities.

At-risk students highly engaged in arts education are 2x more likely than their peers to graduate college, 3x more likely to win an award for school attendance or be elected to class office and 5x less likely to drop out of school.

In the communities where Lalela works, these benefits of arts education are making a difference for kids who were unable to imagine a better future. In South Africa and the South Bronx, gang violence, gender discrimination and sexual violence are daily obstacles to reaching their full potential - or even reaching their school grounds. In Northern Uganda, Lalela works with former child soldiers and orphans from the conflict to develop the creativity and independence that the decades long conflict dangerously damaged. Art allows these students a space where they are safe and encouraged to see beyond their present circumstances. Art provides a venue for expression where there are no right or wrong answers and students can develop the courage of their convictions. Lalela students are the star pupils in their classrooms and excited to go to school - they will be the entrepreneurs and change makers in their communities. It's all a part of the Art of Change.

story:
Colors of Connection created this particular project for Goma, DR Congo to shift perceptions of how women and girls are seen in society. 

What your support will help us achieve:

36 out-of-school adolescent girls and community leaders in Goma will participate in a public arts project the will culminate in the creation of 2 murals addressing girls' rights and girls' protection.

Why working is with girls in Goma, DRC so important ?

Colors of Connection is dedicated to bringing the arts to war-affected populations and DR Congo is one such place that has had a long history of conflict. In staggering fact, the most recent conflict, focused in the eastern region of the country, has resulted in over six million deaths, the largest loss of lives since World War II. Intertwined with the conflict is sexual and gender based violence (SGBV) that is wielded as a weapon of war. It is estimated that 40% of women and girls in the eastern region of Congo have been subjected to sexual violence since 1996.  

Out-of-school adolescent girls in DR Congo are a group that is particularly marginalized and vulnerable to sexual violence as they are socially isolated and lack access to education and support systems that can educate and protect them. 

The Impact

36 out-of-school teenage girls will participate in a 14 week psychosocial arts based program, in which they will have the opportunity to express themselves emotionally through art, learn to protect themselves from sexual violence, understand their rights, and engage as leaders in their community.  The project will culminate in their creation of 2 murals in public spaces in Goma City, in collaboration with community leaders, addressing girls' rights and girls' protection.

During their creation of the murals, the girl participants will be brought into the spotlight of the community, empowered to have a voice in regards to their needs, rights, hopes, and dreams and be able display their talents as leaders and artists.  This process and the product of these collaborative murals in public space will lead to a shift in perceptions of girls and their role in society by the community and the girls themselves. 

This project recognizes that adolescent girls have untapped potential, talent, and importantly a vital voice to add to their community and that the arts are a powerful medium, hugely beneficial in situations of distress and trauma.  

What We Need & What You Get

Our total project budget is $70,000 and we are thrilled that through foundations, in-kind donations and individuals like you we have successfully raised $52,000 = 75% of our budget.  This campaign will help us to raise the remaining 25% of the funds needed to launch the project. 

Your support will go to financing the remaining costs of the project:

  1. Art supplies for mural painting and classroom art lessons $2,500
  2. Food and prizes for teenage girl participants $1,200
  3. Communications for project directors, assistants and translators $1,500
  4. Documentation equipment including photo and video camera and external hard drive $1,500
  5. Salary for a translator $1,300
Perks!
We are excited to have perks ranging from photography and art that will be produced during the project as well as cultural pieces created by three local organizations in Goma:  Kivu Nuru Art et Couture – a local arts market that aims to support the creativity and autonomy of Congolese artists:  kivunuru.com; Heal Africa and the Healing Arts Program who work specifically with women who have experienced sexual and gender-based violence (SGBV) in the region, teaching them a number of arts-based skills that encourage healing, creativity, and networks of solidarity: http://www.healafrica.org; and CAMME (Centre d’Appui en faveur des Mineurs Marginalisés et Exploitées) who offer a variety of programming - including programs focused on arts and culture - to young people in Eastern Congo who are subject to constant discrimination in Congolese society. http://cammedrcongo.org. 
Photos below are of a sampling of the scarves and yoga bags, T-shirt by Kivu Nuru Art et Couture,  and an example of drawings created by one of our youth on our last project.  
      

      


Risks & Challenges

Working in a post-conflict zone such as Goma, DR Congo poses both logistical challenges and security risks.  For this reason we are proud to be working in partnership with the International Rescue Committee (IRC), an international organization who have been working in this region since 1996.  Our partnership with the IRC will ensure that we operate in a way that ensures safety for our staff and the help of a larger experienced organization in problem solving logistic issues as they arise. 

A risk of foreigners entering a new community is that expatriate staff can fail to understand the cultural context, at best being ineffective in their work or at worst, doing more harm than good.  We strive for our staff to apply cultural sensitivity to their work with the community members and individuals during the projects. To help us tackle this challenge we are happy to have one of the lead members of the team, Nadia Fazal work with us on this project.  Nadia has been working in Eastern Congo since 2006 and has come to know and understand the community in Goma.  In addition we will recruit local staff and seek guidance and direction for the project from community leaders.  In general, in our work Colors of Connection follows the recommendations of a culture-centered approach, recognizing that we need to be able to identify the strengths and weaknesses of the specific cultural contexts we work in and to design projects in accordance with this knowledge.

Every project presents its unknown risks and challenges, but so far we’ve successfully  completed every project we’ve set out to do, totaling six public art projects since 2011.  In the refugee camps and post-war towns where we’ve worked, our projects have been met with enthusiastic positive responses from communities, youth, partners and donors.  We invite you to know us and our work better by checking out our website: www.colorsofconnection.org. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that some people are unable to donate, but this doesn't mean you can't help.  If you can't donate spread the word about this campaign because sharing WILL help us reach our goal! 

An easy way to share is to use the Indiegogo share tools.  We also invite you to join us in the conversation about girls’ rights in the DRC using #PaintLikeAGirl, follow us on Facebook, or read more about the project on our website http://www.colorsofconnection.org/projects/cour...

story:
Who We Are & What We're Doing

  • Sharp Teeth Theatre is a Bristol-based theatre company run by Stephanie Kempson which has been curating storytelling, theatre, music and poetry nights in Bristol (mainly at the Wardrobe Theatre). Stephanie Kempson is writer, director and performer who is an associate artist with Mercurial Wrestler, a member of Beyond the Ridiculous, and works and has worked for Bristol Old Vic, Tobacco Factory Theatres, the Wardrobe Theatre, Mayfest, Situations and many other arts organisations. 
  • This production is the culmination of two and half years writing and development on the project for Stephanie, and a year for the rest of the team. We've tested out bits of the show at Camden People's Theatre in London, Tobacco Factory Theatres' Prototype and Bristol Old Vic's Ferment Artist Development festival. The Fox & the Child combines an original story in lyrical prose, specially composed dark ambient folk music and immersive projection.
  • The money will help us create the show to the level we think it deserves. It will help us get specialist rehearsal space, producing support, design support, lighting design support and technical assistance, freeing up the creatives to focus on making the show great!

What We Need & What You Get

Our wish list:

  • We need £1000 to bolster up the money we will make from ticket sales for the performances. This money will allow us to work with a designer, have a technician who can do our lighting and sound, get producing support so we can invite important people in to give us feedback and see the show. It will also help us hire the right projectors, pay for design and any other specialist hires (for example our performer needs a microphone), and rehearsal space. 
  • Our perks range from a thank you in our programme and online, to a downloadable recording of the show, to a postcard story from our writer, or if you're feeling really generous then our writer/performer will write you a story especially for you or a person of your choosing (gift idea alert!). 
  • If we don't reach the entirety of our goal then we'll be focusing on rehearsal space, hiring a projector, our technician and then seeing what else we have the money for.

The Impact

How it will help us:

  • Your contribution will help us make something unique, beautiful and original. We've never seen people doing lyrical prose storytelling with dark folk music and projection in this way, and we can't wait to do it.
  • Without the money the show will get made, but not to anywhere as near a high standard as we want it to be. The more resources we have access to, the better the show will be, and the more likely it will have a future life beyond the Wardrobe Theatre. 
  • We've already secured some in-kind rehearsal space and support, but we have reached a limit with what's available for free. We've been unashamedly asking for lots of things and now is the time we ask you!
  • You'll be supporting some great emerging theatre makers who have a great track record. Director Maisie Newman directed Propolis Theatre's Spill: A Verbatim Show About Sex, composer Rowan Evans has written music for companies such as Tremolo Theatre, projection artist James D Kent has made trailers for Bristol Old Vic and other theatre companies, and performer/writer Stephanie Kempson has written or dramaturged numerous shows for Bristol Old Vic's Young Company (The Gigantic Beard That Was Evil, If You're Lonely, Smokes and Bridges, Conviction), Tobacco Factory Theatre's Young Theatremakers (The Chronicles of Harris Burdick), Hauser & Wirth Somerset and written for companies such as Mercurial Wrestler, Theatre N16, and Part Exchange Company.
  • Plus around 300 people have seen the development of this work, and it would help them to finally learn the end of the story too...
  • Tickets are already on sale and we're already going into rehearsal to develop the show. We'll be blogging about that on Sharp Teeth Theatre's website.

Risks & Challenges

The risks are that we won't have the resources to properly support our show and we'll have to show something which isn't ready, or that we'll burn ourselves out. 

  • We're making sure we pay attention to resourcing the show time-wise as well as in terms physical resources. Making sure our company are paid is a priority which is as important as the work itself. We work a lot for free. It's slightly unrelenting, exhausting and is often at detriment to the work. Working several part-time jobs while also learning lines for a show is pretty hard work.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • If you can't make a donation then please help us by spreading the word on social media or telling your storytelling/theatre-loving friends about this campaign or the show itself.
  • There's even some handy sharing tools below so you can do it right now...
  • Perhaps you might be able to offer us some in-kind support? Lending us a projector or some rehearsal space is just as good, or if you work in the media, give us some air-time!
  • Buy a ticket to watch the show and tell us what you thought!

Thank you!

Other Ways You Can Help

There's even some handy sharing tools below so you can do it right now...

story:
My name is Michele Banks and I’m an artist inspired by science. Many of you know me as Artologica on twitter and etsy.  I’ve been painting cells, bacteria, viruses and more for many years, but I’ve never had the opportunity to work with real scientists in a lab – until now! I’ve been selected to be the Artist-in-Residence at the Kilpisjärvi Biological Station in Finland in October and November 2015. I’m very excited about this opportunity to enrich my science-art work, and I need your help to make it happen.

Ars Bioarctica and Kilpisjärvi Biological Station

The Ars Bioarctica Residency Program is a joint project of the Finnish Bioart Society and the Kilpisjärvi Biological Station in sub-Arctic Lapland. The residency focuses on the Arctic environment and art and science collaboration.

The Kilpisjärvi Biological Station offers the artists-in-residence the opportunity to work closely with its scientists and staff. This includes access to scientific equipment, laboratory facilities, the library and seminar room as well as the use of field equipment. The station, which is a part of the University of Helsinki, supports the work of many long-range research projects on vegetation, local fauna and soil chemistry, among others. Its location near the Arctic Circle puts it on the front lines of climate change, a subject of much of my recent art.

What will I do there?

This is not a studio residency, so I don’t expect to be coming home with bundles of finished paintings. It’s mainly an opportunity for me to watch, learn and listen. I plan to explore the Arctic landscape, observe the scientists, gather some samples, peer through microscopes, ask a lot of questions, take a lot of pictures, and do some sketching and painting.

(This is Kilpisjärvi. Pretty nice, huh?)

Then, after I come home, I’ll process all this new information and use it to create new, deeper, stronger artwork. I also plan to write and talk about the experience of artist-scientist collaboration, and I hope to have an exhibition of the work inspired by my residency. 

That said, there's no end product to this project. This residency is an experience, a unique opportunity for me to learn and grow as an artist, and your support will help me to take full advantage of it.

What will your contribution cover?

Like most art residencies, this one is unfunded. I hope to raise enough money through Indiegogo to cover the following expenses:

  • Flights and ground transportation to and from Kilpisjärvi
  • Room and board expenses at the Biological Station
  • Art materials, equipment and supplies

What do you get as a thank you? 

I'm so excited about the opportunity to go to Finland and work with scientists that I've come up with some great perks to thank the people who are supporting me.

The Reindeer Moss Print 

  • For a $25 contribution, I'll send you a postcard from Finland! 
  • I've created a design based on reindeer moss (Cladonia rangiferina), a type of lichen found in the Arctic, and I'm offering it to contributors on beautiful prints and silk scarves for contributions ranging from $15 - $75.                                                                                    

  • The Reindeer Moss Scarf

  • For a $200 contribution, I'll paint you a one-of-a-kind original painting based on my work at the station.  

Risks & Challenges

Finland is a pretty safe place, but I guess I might get eaten by a polar bear. 

Seriously, though, there is very little risk to this project. I've already committed to the residency, so that means I'm going to do it. And I've already ordered your scarves.

Anything I raise over the goal will buy more art supplies so I can make more art! 
If you have any questions or concerns, please feel free to email me. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to contribute money to the campaign, please help spread the word by tweeting the campaign, posting it to Facebook,  pinning it, and telling all your sciency and arty friends about it! 

Also, anything you buy from my etsy shop helps pay the bills and allows me to save money for this residency.

finished paintings. It’s mainly an opportunity for me to watch, learn and
listen. I plan to explore the Arctic landscape, observe the scientists, gather
some samples, peer through microscopes, ask a lot of questions, take a lot of
pictures, and do some sketching and painting.


(This is Kilpisjärvi. Pretty nice, huh?)
Then,
after I come home, I’ll process all this new information and use it to create
new, deeper, stronger artwork. I also plan to write and talk about the
experience of artist-scientist collaboration, and I hope to have an exhibition
of the work inspired by my residency. 
That said, there's no end product to this project. This residency is an experience, a unique opportunity for me to learn and grow as an artist, and your support will help me to take full advantage of it.
What will your contribution cover?
Like
most art residencies, this one is unfunded. I hope to raise enough money
through Indiegogo to cover the following expenses:



Flights and ground
transportation to and from Kilpisjärvi


Room and board
expenses at the Biological Station


Art materials,
equipment and supplies


What do you get as a thank you? 
I'm
so excited about the opportunity to go to Finland and work with scientists that
I've come up with some great perks to thank the people who are supporting me.


The Reindeer Moss Print 



For a $25
contribution, I'll send you a postcard from Finland! 

I've created a design
based on reindeer moss (Cladonia rangiferina), a type of lichen found in the Arctic, and I'm offering it to contributors on beautiful prints and silk scarves for
contributions ranging from $15 - $75.                                                                                    
The Reindeer Moss Scarf

For a $200
contribution, I'll paint you a one-of-a-kind original painting based on my work
at the station.  



  Risks & Challenges

Finland is a pretty safe place, but I guess I might get eaten by a polar bear. 


Seriously, though, there is very little risk to this project. I've already committed to the residency, so that means I'm going to do it. And I've already ordered your scarves.

Anything I raise over the goal will buy more art supplies so I can make more art! 
If you have any questions or concerns, please feel free to email me. 
 Other Ways You Can Help
 If you are not able to contribute money to the campaign, please help spread the word by tweeting the campaign, posting it to Facebook,  pinning it, and telling all your sciency and arty friends about it! 
Also, anything you buy from my etsy shop helps pay the bills and allows me to save money for this residency.

story:
THE BOOK OF BEEZUS

Black Rock City: the land of dust and honey. Amid the sin and suffering, Beezus rises to grant sweet salvation, offering you his flesh and blood in the form of honey and mead. He has saved you twice before and, in 2015, he is resurrected yet again so that you may thirst not.

But seriously: Beezus Christ, Super Car is a bee mutant vehicle born in 2013 from the mind of Michelle "Smallfry" Lessans with help from an amazing group of friends. He currently lives at NIMBY, a fantastic maker space in East Oakland. We serve honey from Burners around the globe at our fabulous honey bar, along with home-brewed mead for those seeking a little more levity. For the past two years, we've brought honey from Poland, Malaysia, and beyond!

It seems like it's already built. Why should I back this project?

Otherwise, he will SMITE you! Actually, we’ve planned even more upgrades of biblical proportions to make Beezus bigger, better, and more bee-utiful than ever before. There's a lot to fund, and we appreciate all the support we can get. Here’s the breakdown:

• New lights! We're upgrading Beezus' old rope lights to LEDs that will do some bee-utifil color fades to make him shine at night! We're also 3D printing a nifty honey-drop shaped chandelier to hang from the inside for extra ambient lighting.

• New flower petals! After experimenting with a design for last year's flower petals, we've decided to go with something a little more streamlined. Everyone loves an aerodynamic bee!

• Repairs! Between crusing the playa and living outdoors in East Oakland for the past two years, Beezus has experienced a good amount of wear and tear. His motor needs a lot of lovin' to get up and running again. Aside from that, we've got to manage some rust and fix the wiring in Beezus' drive system to keep him buzzing safely.

• New Batteries! Unfortunately batteries don't last forever, and we're about due for some new ones to keep Beezus out all day and night.

If we don’t meet our overall goal, Beezus will still grace us with his presence on the playa! But the closer we get, the more money we’ll have to make him as efficient, mobile, and bee-utiful as possible. 

PLUS: THE REWARDS OF FOLLOWING BEEZUS

We’ve got stellar gifts for all who donate! Stickers! New bandanas! Pendants! Local Honey in custom mason jar glasses! Excessive enthusiasm, eternal gratitude, and infinite exclamation points! We've got it ALL!

Whether or not you’re able to donate, help us spread the gospel of our savior! Tell your friends, tell your mom, tell your weird neighbor. Tell your boss. Tell that guy on the bus. Write about it in your family newsletter. Blog about it, tweet about it, share our link on Facebook. Let everyone know that Beezus is here to save them! #BeezusSaves

*Special thanks to Mark Day for making our video, everyone who has contributed to Beezus in the past, and to NIMBY for being such an amazing space to build in!

story:
Hello everyone,

My name is Andrea Chung and I am a visual artist. I've been invited to present my collaborative project, Catchin' Babies, Colonizing Black Bodies, at this year's Black Portraiture Conference in Johannesburg, South Africa, held at the University of the Witwatersrand. I will be presenting all the artwork made based on our research of Jamaican "nana" midwives in 2014.

Here is a brief description of our presentation:

"The bodies of Black women as mothers and birth attendants have been heralded as deviant, unclean, promiscuous, and innately pathological within the Western medical establishment.  Consequently, in an effort to stave off diseases that supposedly Black bodies carried, the interdependent relationship between the medical and legal professions justified a persistent subjugation and persecution of the Black female midwives in the U.S. and in the Caribbean in the late 1800s through the mid-1900s. This project and artwork seek to discuss the ways in which Black midwives and birthing mothers resisted by passing along intergenerational knowledge of healing and birthing traditions within the African diaspora.  This work seeks to make visible their contributions to the survival of Black birthing subcultures and beliefs while also outlining how Foucault’s concept of biopolitics is a useful lens to view how nation states engage in corralling the Black female form. "

I am asking for your assistance towards the airfare and housing. $2,000 will cover both airfare ($1,200) and housing.  The conference is 11/17 - 11/19 but due to the distance my travel dates will be 11/14 - 11/20.

For those of you unfamiliar, click the link for more information about previous Black Portraiture conferences.Any donation big or small helps. Frequent flyer miles welcome. If you can't contribute, tell a friend!

Also, the art world is small so there will be other artists who will be doing fundraising campaigns as well. I ask that you try assist them as well. $1,200 is a feat for those of us trying to pay rent/mortgages and hold down a studio. This is a very important conference and all artists need your generous support. 

Thank you!

********************

Andrea Chung explores themes of labor and materials and their relationships with post-colonial countries. Chung is interested in the imbued histories that materials, such as sugar, carry and how they also carry with them the stories of human transmission and the long lasting effects of colonialism on tropical ‘post-colonial’ societies such as the Caribbean and the Indian Ocean. She received a BFA at Parsons School of Design in New York and a MFA at the Mount Royal School of Art at the Maryland Institute College of Art (MICA) in Baltimore. Chung has participated in several residencies including the Skowhegan School of Painting and Sculpture, the Headlands, Vermont Studio Center, the McColl Center for Visual Arts and the Joan Mitchell Center.

Andrea Chung has exhibited at Syracuse University, McColl Center for Visual Arts, National Gallery of Jamaica, Arthouse, Art Museum of the Americas, Medulla Gallery in Trinidad, Arlington Arts Center, apexart, Deutsche Bank, MoCADA, UNC Chapel Hill, Royal West of England Academy and Punkt Ø F 15 in Norway. Her work will be featured in the Getty’s 2017 Pacific Standard Time biennale in Los Angeles.

Chung was the recipient of a Fulbright Scholarship, an Art Matters Grant and a Joan Mitchell Award and has lectured at MICA, Tulane, University of Delaware and the Claremont Colleges. Her work has been published in ARC, Small Axe, Harvard’s Transitions and Representations and the Huffington Post.

Andrea Chung lives and works in San Diego, CA.
