story:
As a child I used to fill my older sisters' shoeboxes with all kinds of stuff from the yard, around the house and from the foreboding darkness of the cellar. When I thought there were enough objects in the box, I would put the lid back on and shake it up and remove it in order to discover how, "they rearranged themselves". These were travel boxes. Though the contents were the same, their repositioning made the inside of the box appear like a different place each time I removed the lid.

I did my first large-scale interactive public sculpture, "Occupy AIR" in 2012. As an Artist In Residency in Tuzla, BiH, I built the word Occupy in wood like a room with out a roof on the 20th year commemorating the Bosnian/Serbian war. It was 15 meters long and 5 meters wide at 2 meters in height.  And after seeing thousands of names etched in stone of those who died in the war, the sculpture Occupy AIR was entered by 180 citizens of Tuzla who wrote their names on it's interior walls, transforming the sculpture into a living monument to life. 

That's me directing traffic inside Occupy AIR.


The video Occupy AIR:


I had 3 weeks to fund raise, lecture, build and produce a documentary DVD and without the engagement and humanity of the citizens of Tuzla, I would not have been able to accomplish what was my maiden voyage into building Outdoor Public Sculpture and their potential. But I was unsatisfied with the structural details and so a promise was made to somehow gain another opportunity to implement what I learned in Tuzla, for another City.


Redemption came with a commission by the Federal Chancellery of Austria to represent the country at the 2014 Centennial in Sarajevo. I built my second interactive sculpture in a modified shape of the word "Outsourcing" titled, O2S14 "Outsourcing to Sarajevo 2014".

What's in a word can depend on what you put into it.

When asked by the Chancellery what I would be outsourcing I said that it was they who are outsourcing me (an American) to represent them (Austria) and that I would outsource the content (inside of the sculpture) to 14 artists from Austria and Bosnia and Herzegovina and France, by hiring them to submit an image of their work, formatting the digital files into PVC wall paper that would cover the entire interior of the sculpture including the floor. 

June 28th, 2014. It was 100 years after Austria's Arch Duke Franz Ferdinand had been assassinated June 28th 1914 triggering  a chain of reactions that brought on WW1. But in this region, (The Balkans), with 50% unemployment and having been passed over by international investors, the last thing the citizens needed was to commemorate another war. Disenfranchised by the global market due to the gross internal conflict, commercial and intellectual investment is scarce. O2S14 recognized this misjudgment and saw the Balkans as fertile ground for the creative process to encompass the infinity of human nature in all its state(s), where it welcomes one's past and present and nothing is left behind nor denied but syphoned through the sculpture's framework as an act of reclamation of one's own part in defining the moment, culture and content.


O2S14 Outsourcing to Sarajevo, was more an occasion to celebrate the day rather than mourn the date. And by the expressions on their faces and the way the community engaged with the sculpture, O2S14 was turned into an inverted 21C Trojan horse that was invaded by citizens with an appetite for action and art. 

Here, instead of a large outdoor public sculpture pretending to have omnipotent powers by over staying its welcome and occupying public grounds, O2S14 was designed as a temporary sculpture that allowed the public to occupy its' space becoming a viable component to its content and after 2 weeks, to be removed enticing memory to sustain it.

I believe this work touches people like a Carol King song (not in the video). The video, O2S14:

Now I have the chance to do the project again in Vienna as O2V15 "Outsourcing to Vienna" 2015, at the Museums Quartier, Vienna with the same amount of artists from Aut and BiH but with an additional 3 American artists to remove the sculpture from its regulatory role of commemoration to a more contemporary context of inclusion.

The "Corner Stones" of O2V15 laying out the placement for the sculpture: Ulrike Fallmann Lt, (curator), Klaus Gruber Rt, (architect) and me in the far center holding a sign. Museums Quartier, Vienna, AUT.

But the numbers are high and I'm trying to be realistic in only seeking €45,850. through this campaign. I've already done this piece in Sarajevo with the funding of the Austrian government who won't fund this project as it's part of a Public Museum's program. But I know as it was yesterday, the thrill we all had when the public entered what they thought was a classically stoic, enclosed modernist sculpture, only to open up to  be a brightly colorful and oddly spacious labyrinth of imagery with the open sky above. I promised myself to do this work again in the city (Vienna) that trusted me with the task of representing them, knowing that the cost would be considerably higher and the chances of not raising the funds even greater as a foreign artist working primarily independently.

Principle Costs: €45,850.

I've already invested: €3250. 
Architect/Engineer's fee: Administrative, consulting including preparing documents, filling costs (in order to push the paperwork through) and get it approved by the municipalities here known as the MA37. This had to be paid regardless of whether or not the sculpture is approved and built.

The digital formatting, printing and installation of the PVC wallpaper: €10,200. 
Contractors fee: €32,400.
  1. 4 carpenters.
  2. Materials, mainly wood with steel fasteners.
  3. Rental  of off-site facility to build the sculpture in sections.
  4. Fire retardant treatment and painting of wood (traffic red).
  5. Delivery. 
  6. Installation in concert with the PVC wall paper team.
  7. De-installation.
  8. Delivery to lucky selected donatee.
Additional costs will inevitably be incurred: €19,100.
  1. Promotion: €900. Fliers, posters printing and distribution, blog updating. 
  2. Documentation: €4700. Ground and aerial crew with:
  3. HD video cam and digital photography with mobile crane: €1500.
  4. Drone team: €3200, crew of 3, pilot, camera operator and asst.
  5. Post production: €1600. Video editing/formatting for the Web and DVDs
  6. 24 hour Security: €7200, One guard per 8 hour shift for 23 days.
  7. Original music sound tract for the official O2V15 DVD.

Total costs: €64,950.
Of course this does not cover my time and all investments during the campaign period which certainly extends beyond the 60 days of this particular  fundraising campaign. 

The goal with my outdoor sculptures is to create platforms that encourage public engagement, contributing to the creative content of the moment. Each day we are challenged to navigate changes to our perceptions of space. Within the walls of O2V15 we are invited into a visual play with language and architecture  unencumbered with the day-to-day trappings found on the pedestrian pathway.

Thank you!
Alexander Viscio
NEXT STOP: USA Home!


 

Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • Introduce yourself and your background.
  • Briefly describe your campaign and why it's important to you.
  • Express the magnitude of what contributors will help you achieve.

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • Explain how much funding you need and where it's going. Be transparent and specific-people need to trust you to want to fund you.
  • Tell people about your unique perks. Get them excited!
  • Describe where the funds go if you don't reach your entire goal.

The Impact

Feel free to explain more about your campaign and let people know how the difference their contribution will make:

  • Explain why your project is valuable to the contributor and to the world.
  • Point out your successful track record with projects like this (if you have one).
  • Make it real for people and build trust.

Risks & Challenges

People value your transparency. Be open and stand out by providing insight into the risks and obstacles you may face on the way to achieving your goal.

  • Share what qualifies you to overcome these hurdles.
  • Describe your plan for solving these challenges.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Beu-Bye 14 au Théâtre de la Bordée, du 11 au 20 décembre à 19h30.

Présentée sous forme de sketchs, chansons, danses et numéros de variétés, Beu-Bye 14, la revue de l’année de Québec, revisite les faits marquants de l’actualité 2014. Vous y retrouverez Régis Labeaume cherchant du financement auprès de Séraphin Poudrier. On vous explique comment bien voter aux prochaines élections et qui sera le nouveau chef du Parti Québecois tandis qu’une émission culinaire réunira les chefs Ricardo, à la Di Stasio, Curieux Bégin, Daniel Vézina et toutes autres vedettes du Québec pour un ultime souper presque parfait.

D'autre part, un artiste-sculpteur français viendra compléter la production. Le but de cette collaboration est de proposer une rétrospective globale: la vision intérieure sera assurée par l'auteur et les interprètes, tandis que le regard extérieur sur l'actualité québécoise sera pris en charge par Castor Vervaren, sculpteur sur métal français.

La Compagnie

Le collectif du Temps qui s'arrête offre un théâtre de création nouveau genre, au public de Québec et d’ailleurs. Il intègre différentes formes d’art à ses œuvres, telles que la musique (La Fanfare avec le groupe DCL), la danse (Danse de garçons avec la compagnie Danse K par K), et la radio (L’Gros Show). Théâtre de combat devant la bêtise humaine, c’est aussi un théâtre du cœur et d’urgence. A caractère social, il mélange les générations et se fixe comme objectif de rejoindre le plus grand nombre de spectateurs possible. Théâtre accessible à la recherche d’actualité, de beauté, de fragilité humaine et surtout un théâtre vrai, sensible.

Sa première création, La Fanfare a été mise en nomination dans la catégorie Meilleur spectacle de la relève catégorie théâtre au prix Première Ovation en 2010. Le second spectacle, salué par la critique, Danse de garçons, co-produit par la compagnie pour le Carrefour international de théâtre 2013 sera repris au théâtre Périscope à Québec et à Montréal au cours de la saison 2014-2015. Quant à sa plus récente production L’Gros Show, elle est apparue dans la section « pièces favorites d’Eric Moreault » – le Soleil – en 2013.

Pourquoi nous aider?

Le montant que nous demandons servira à assurer les frais de productions : scénographie, costumes, accessoires, pour que la pièce puisse prendre toute l’ampleur dont elle a besoin. Même si nous avons l’imagination fertile et que nous travaillons à réduire sans cesse les coûts de production, la réalisation demande un minimum de financement.

De plus, vous pourrez profiter d’une visibilité auprès de plus de 2500 personnes dans la ville de Québec.

Une revue de l’année manque cruellement dans la Capitale Nationale à l’approche des fêtes de fin d’année. En nous aidant, vous soutiendrez un projet rassembleur autour de sujets d’actualité dont nous avons tous entendu parler en plus de soutenir la relève artistique de la région.

Comment nous aider?

En venant voir le résultat final au Théâtre de la Bordée du 11 au 20 décembre à 19h30.

Et bien sûr, en nous aidant financièrement, pour donner à ce projet le coup de pouce dont il a besoin.

De plus, si vous avez une entreprise, nous pouvons vous assurer une belle visibilité dans la Ville de Québec.

Mais surtout, n’hésitez pas à en parler autour de vous.

L’équipe de production

Écriture                                                Collectif

Mise en scène                                    Lucien Ratio

Conseiller à la réalisation              Jean-Jacqui Boutet

Assistant à la mise en scène        Marc Brouillette

Interprètes                                         Joëlle Bourdon

                                                               Philippe Durocher

                                                               Edwige Morin

                                                               Monika Pilon

                                                               Lucien Ratio 

                                                               Nicola-Frank Vachon

 

Scénographe                                     Marie Mc Nicoll

Conception d'éclairage                  Jean-François Labbé

Conception musicale                      Mathieu Campagna


Direction artistique                         Lucien Ratio

Direction des communications   Philippe Durocher

Direction de production                 Edwige Morin

story:
WeSLAM is Wesleyan University's slam poetry team, and we are trying to get to the College Unions Poetry Slam Invitational in La Verne, California, in April 2012.

CUPSI is the largest collegiate poetry competition in the country, with college teams coming from all across the 50 states to compete. 2012 will be our second year at CUPSI--in our rookie year, we finished 7th in the nation and took home the coveted Spirit of the Slam Award as well as the prize for Best Persona Poem.

We believe we can do even better this year.

But in order for us to get there, we need YOUR help. This year, the competition is going to be held in April at the University of La Verne in California and expenses run high: there's airfare, registration fees, and hotel reservations. We are setting up this Indiegogo, which will allow you, the user, to pledge ANY AMOUNT OF MONEY to our cause. If you can't pledge money, consider donating a Facebook or Twitter status.

WeSLAM isn't even two years old, but has already reached out to multitudes of audience members and fellow poets on campus. WeSLAM has a diverse range of voices, from freshmen to seniors, from California to New York, from Tennessee to Vermont. Moreover, when we refer to weSLAM we're not referring only to the 5 poets on our team, but the whole poetry and slam community at Wes -- a community that has shown unmatched amounts of love and support since our inception.  WeSLAM has earned a reputation in the slam world for rolling with a mob-sized family because we have always travelled with an entourage of WesPoets supporting us at every go.  

So, our reach extends far past Wesleyan itself. WeSLAM won the Wade-Lewis Poetry Slam Invitational in 2011 and has twice been awarded the Spirit of the Slam (CUPSI 2011 and Yale Regional Slam 2012), an award that goes to the team that best embodies what slam is supposed to be all about: heart, enthusiasm, passion, community.

We're going to CUPSI because we want to share our voices again and we want to hear from others and learn from them in the process. This will allow for the betterment of the arts community at Wesleyan and a voice in the slam poetry community at large.

Every cent will get us closer to CUPSI, so contribute whatever you are comfortable with.

This also benefits you, dear reader, as there are incentives for donations exceeding $4--including CDs of our recorded work and an opportunity to have an original poem written by one of the team members about you or a topic of your choosing.

Remember, ANY AMOUNT OF MONEY will help.

Donate your statuses! Share this with all your friends!

Thank y'all so much! We'll see you in April at University of La Verne!

WeSLAM 2012 is:

  • Solomon Billinkoff '14 (the guy in the video) 
  • Izzy Coleman '15
  • Nate Mondschein '12
  • Nick Petrie '12
  • Emily Weitzman '14

For every $50 raised we will post a video of another poem from the WeSLAM community, so get sharing!
story_txt:
WeSLAM is Wesleyan University's slam poetry team, and we are trying to get to the College Unions Poetry Slam Invitational in La Verne, California, in April 2012.

CUPSI is the largest collegiate poetry competition in the country, with college teams coming from all across the 50 states to compete. 2012 will be our second year at CUPSI--in our rookie year, we finished 7th in the nation and took home the coveted Spirit of the Slam Award as well as the prize for Best Persona Poem. 
We believe we can do even better this year.But in order for us to get there, we need YOUR help. This year, the competition is going to be held in April at the University of La Verne in California and expenses run high: there's airfare, registration fees, and hotel reservations. We are setting up this Indiegogo, which will allow you, the user, to pledge ANY AMOUNT OF MONEY to our cause. If you can't pledge money, consider donating a Facebook or Twitter status.
WeSLAM isn't even two years old, but has already reached out to multitudes of audience members and fellow poets on campus. WeSLAM has a diverse range of voices, from freshmen to seniors, from California to New York, from Tennessee to Vermont. Moreover, when we refer to weSLAM we're not referring only to the 5 poets on our team, but the whole poetry and slam community at Wes -- a community that has shown unmatched amounts of love and support since our inception.  WeSLAM has earned a reputation in the slam world for rolling with a mob-sized family because we have always travelled with an entourage of WesPoets supporting us at every go.  
So, our reach extends far past Wesleyan itself. WeSLAM won the Wade-Lewis Poetry Slam Invitational in 2011 and has twice been awarded the Spirit of the Slam (CUPSI 2011 and Yale Regional Slam 2012), an award that goes to the team that best embodies what slam is supposed to be all about: heart, enthusiasm, passion, community. 
We're going to CUPSI because we want to share our voices again and we want to hear from others and learn from them in the process. This will allow for the betterment of the arts community at Wesleyan and a voice in the slam poetry community at large.
Every cent will get us closer to CUPSI, so contribute whatever you are comfortable with.
This also benefits you, dear reader, as there are incentives for donations exceeding $4--including CDs of our recorded work and an opportunity to have an original poem written by one of the team members about you or a topic of your choosing.Remember, ANY AMOUNT OF MONEY will help.Donate your statuses! Share this with all your friends! 
Thank y'all so much! We'll see you in April at University of La Verne!

Izzy Coleman '15
Nate Mondschein '12
Nick Petrie '12
Emily Weitzman '14
For every $50 raised we will post a video of another poem from the WeSLAM community, so get sharing!

story:
help me make awesome stuff for you to wear!

i've always joked about "that would make a good tshirt" and have dosens of tshirt designs floating around on scrap paper, stuck in drawers, filed away in cabinets, or sitting in abandoned folders on my computer box.


i've been talking about this long enough. i figure now i should do something about it...


i'm going to start a screen printing business.

but why can't you just use zazzle, or cafe press, or...

those services end up being very expensive. yes, they have a great product and i fully support those businesses for personal tshirts. but if i design a tshirt for you, it ends up costing close to $30 for a tshirt. i don't know about you.. but that's too expensive for me.


i want to offer my tshirts at near cost. the only way i can do that is to make them myself.

sounds great, but why do you need over $2,000?

i'm starting completely from scratch here. i have a perfect space for screen printing, but i have nothing else. i need screens, a press, tshirts, ink, squeegies, a light box (or the supplies to make one), emulsion, transparencies, you name it!


i've done lots of research and sought out deals to find the least possible amount i would need to get started. i'll also be spending a lot of my own money on this venture, but this will at least give me a head start so i can start making stuff that you can wear.

want to help?

i appreciate any help you can offer. if you can donate some cash, that's amazing. if you can't afford to donate now, if you can just pass this on to your friends and family, that is just as helpful to me.

thanks!

story:
Breaking Code.

Part of the 2014 National Queer Arts Festival.

 

Many of our communities have not yet embraced candid conversation about mental health. 

On June 9th, 2014 seventeen Queer and Trans artists based in Ohio, North Carolina, Massachusetts, New York and the San Francisco Bay Area will come together to break the code of silence that tells us we are alone, we are broken, we are wrong.

 

For many, speaking about mental health is yet another coming out process. Breaking Code showcases visual and performing artists

 exploring the ways ‘Queer’ and ‘Crazy’ have been forced together and forced apart. Together we use the tools of reclamation and subversion, that many of us develop as we come to a queer identity, to rethink our relationship to mental health.

But we need your support!

*************************************************************************

Breaking Code's performance and visual art opening is on June 9th, 2014 @ San Francisco’s LGBT Center. Exhibit Reception: 6pm-7pm. Performance: 7pm. The visual arts exhibit will be up from June 2nd - July 18th. 

This campaign does not just fund transformative work, it shatters isolation. By donating you add your name to the growing list of  people working to reduce the stigma surrounding both mental health and queerness.

This $2,000 will: 

  • Pay for our venue rental, $300. 

  • Cover the cost of shipping artwork from artists outside of the Bay Area, $100 

  • Pay for artist stipends to support the creation of this incredible work, $1,600.

We chose the “Fixed” funding option. This means it’s all or nothing. If we do not make our $2,000 goal than we get $0. We chose this option so that we could be sure to pay our artists in a timely manner and because we believe in the support of our communities! 

Still, we wanted to sweeten the pot! As an incentive many of our artists have offered original artwork, handmade gifts and home cooked meals. Look to the right and choose your gift of gratitude!

************************************************************************

This Is Who You Are Supporting

Check out the incredible artists of Breaking Code!

Performing Artists

  • The Lady Ms. Vagina Jenkins

  • Meliza Bañales

  • Dirty D

  • Kentucky Fried Woman

  • Renee Garcia

  • Nicole Goodwin

  • Manish V.

  • A Thimble of Light

  • Mister Ri Molnar

  • Leah Lakshmi Piepzna-Samarasinha

Visual Artists

  • LOSTBOY

  • Heidi Andrea Restrepo Rhodes

  • Micah Bazant

  • Catherine Edgerton

  • Jos Truitt

  • Becka Shertzer

Curators

  • Blyth Barnow

  • E. Oscar Maynard

*************************************************************************

Still Want To Help?

  • Share this campaign on Facebook and Twitter! Tell people why you think it's important!

  • Email this page to 5 people who are dear to you and ask them if they would be willing to contribute!

  • Join us on June 9th at the LGBT Center in San Francisco! RSVP here!

  • Connect with us on Facebook and Twitter!

  • In the Bay Area? Join our Outreach Team to help spread the word about June 9th's event!

 *************************************************************************

Thank you for your incredible support! 

With Heart and Gratitude,

The Artists of Breaking Code


* Music by Nomy Lamm *

story:
Valentine's Day Can Mean Something Else

A holiday about love should be about love, not about consumerism and romantic expectations. 

This Valentine's Day I'm going to plant myself in the food court of Cherryhill Village Mall and hand out personalized Valentine's cards to anyone that wants one and for as long as I still have cards to give away. 

What is Needed & What You Get

  • I would love to be able to give a card to everyone I meet on Valentine's Day. This is a difficult number to predict so the more cards the better. 
  • All donations will be used to buy Valentine's cards. If donations exceed my wildest expectations or there are cards left over I will use them to do something bigger and lovelier next year.
  • All those who donate $10 or more will get a Valentine's card personalized by someone I meet during a card exchange. 

Alternative Donations

  • Maybe you want to come and join me on Friday to write and hand out cards. Great! Please contact me directly. I'd love to spend the day with you. 
  • If you have extra cards at home you won't be using I'd be happy to put them to good use. Please sign your name on them so our new friends know who the generous donor is.

story:
Please Help Frame Original Illustrations by Roger Tory Peterson and Create a Traveling Exhibit of Never Before Displayed Art. 

Roger Tory Peterson (1908-1996) is considered 20th century America's king of bird watching and nature education. The Roger Tory Peterson Institute of Natural History (RTPI) is a small not-for-profit organization located in Peterson's hometown of Jamestown, New York, where we offer nature education programs and exhibits in the spirit of our hero. The Institute's archival vaults preserve over 200,000 works of art and other items that frame the arc of Peterson's spectacular career. Peterson considered himself first and formost an educator and we intend to continue his life's work by making his work available to a wide audience. 

Roger Tory Peterson's paintings and illustrations, reproduced in millions of field guides, books and magazines over several decades, inspired generations of Americans to know and love nature. Through much of his career the most practical and economical way to make his point was in black and white. Although Peterson is not best known for the black and white illustrations that graced several of his popular books, his pen-and-ink drawings are brilliantly executed gems that have never before been exhibited! The Roger Tory Peterson Institute wants to frame several of the original illustrations from our collection and send them on the road for new generations of artists, nature-lovers and environmentalists across the country to enjoy.

RTPI plans to have expertly framed 50 of the best Peterson's original illustrations from How to Know the Birds (1949), Wild America (1955), The Bird Watcher's Anthology (1959), and Penguins (1979). Our picture framer, a longtime friend and supporter of our Institute, has given us a fantastic deal to do the job. The cost of framing each illustration ($150) includes high-quality conservation framing to ensure the continued protection of the original artwork (acid-free mattes, unbreakable plexiglass that protects from harmful UV radiation, etc.) and also includes durable packaging so that these pieces can be shipped to other venues across the country as part of a traveling exhibit.

Please help us raise the funds necessary to get this framing done, to get these priceless jewels out of our vault and into nature centers and museums where thousands of people can enjoy and learn from them.

story:
Greetings, fine folks!

 

My name is Christine Kuhn and I'm a professional artist.  I guess that what makes me a professional artist is the fact that I support myself through teaching art lessons and through grants and through the sale of my art.  I am a self taught artist; I loved art so much that I gave up a science career to pursue my passion.  It has been an invigorating and sometimes frightening journey, but I am glad that I had the courage to begin and the courage to continue in spite of moments of great doubt.  

In this campaign, I am trying to raise the remainder of funds for a month long artists' residency at the Vermont Studio Center, beginning on May 13, 2013.  The studio center has offered me a partial scholarship and work study funds and I have also received funds from the Kentucky Arts Council and LexArts.  However, more funds are needed for me to be able to take advantage of this unique opportunity.  

 

To be able to attend an artist residency here in the US means a great deal to me and to the progression of my art.  As a self-taught artist, I have much to gain from interaction with other artists; it's something I have rarely encountered.  Imagine that you had never had any work colleagues . . . . how far do you feel you would have progressed in your profession with neither personal nor institutional support? Just alone, in your garage, on your own time and your own dime.  Would you have learned what you know now and at the rate that you have learned? Answer this question for yourself honestly and you'll see how this opportunity will accelerate my learning process.  I want to be an amazing artist.  I have the discipline and the smarts necessary to do so; I just need a little more interaction and maybe some healthy competition.  

So, why in the heck is art important in the first place??  Why should you donate to an ART project when there are so many good causes out there? Well, truth is, art is one of the few activities that touches and relieves the main source of trouble in the modern world which is personal fear and anxiety.  Greed, violence, prejudice and knee-jerk reactions of every sort all boil down to fear--fear of not having enough, fear of being hurt, losing something, etc. Inexplicably, art has the power to reach the subconscious mind and release the energy of fear, as well as other emotional energy blockages.  Just imagine what would happen if folks too as good care of their emotions as they do their physical bodies! It would be a real cultural revolution.

If you give to this campaign, your funds will be used to pay for the balance of the artist's residency, for travel to the residency and for art supplies used during the residency period.  

If you give $25, you'll get a 6-card set of note cards featuring my art work and hand selected by you from my many pieces.  If you give $100, you can either receive 4 free private art lessons or one of my small paintings (of your own choice) that usually sells for $175.  So, it's  a great way to either learn a new skill or build your art collection on a budget! :D 

If all the funds needed aren't raised, I will use whatever funds are donated for the residency fees and borrow the rest of the money for the residency.  So, either way, your donation will help me attend! :D

If you are unable to give at this time, no worries, but please take a moment to share this campaign with others--let them know that they can make the world a more beautiful place by supporting an artist!

story:
Thursday June 26th, 2014
5 pm and 6:30 pm

TROPHIES

featuring the masks of ROLAND GEBHARDT
and the legendary music of
MOONDOG performed by
LOUIS NICOLIA and HALF MOON CONSORT
choreography by MERCEDES SEARER

JACK HANLEY GALLERY
327 Broom Street New York, NY

Admission free


What happens when an international sculptor discovers a musician who preserves and performs the work of a legendary musician?

In the secluded community of Chautauqua, New York, at the LakeArts Foundation Incubator, such a thing happened — New York artist Roland Gebhardt met musician Louis Nicolia. The result is TROPHIES, an inspired collaboration, bringing together sculpture, modern dancers, and the music
of Moondog.

With TROPHIES Gebhardt has created a provocative look at the art collector as hunter and art as a trophy to be pursued, captured and displayed on a wall.

Collecting trophies is a common social pursuit. Objects of perceived and real value are used as icons to express one's identity. Trophies are currency of social stature. In this performance piece, establishing and collecting hunting trophies serve as the analogy.

The music is by Moondog, a blind street musician who rose from the sidewalks of New York’s 6th Avenue to influence composers such as Phillip Glass, Peter Sellars, Steve Reich, Jon Gibson and Frank Zappa.

In TROPHIES it is dance and music that instill abstract masks with life. In this performance — second in an evolving international tour of varying iterations of the piece that introduces new dancers in each city — choreographer Mercedes Searer will join dancers Macklin Kowal and Alexander Leslie Thompson in an athletic, feral interpretation. The music of Moondog will be played by the Half Moon Consort chamber ensemble, founded by violinist Nicolia.

Nicolia’s Consort musicians are dedicated to furthering Moondog’s musical legacy. All are skilled performers of the music of "the Viking of Sixth Avenue” and have performed in numerous venues and cities, including Carnegie Hall.


About the Artists

Roland Gebhardt is an internationally known sculptor and designer. In 2008 he debuted The Only Tribe, his first live theater piece for masks, which featured choreography by Peter Kyle and video design by Reid Farrington, at New York's 3LD Art & Technology Center. Best known for his monolithic sculptures, Gebhardt's work has been shown around the world and is in many prominent collections. He studied at both the Art Academy of Hamburg and the Kunstgewerbeschule in Zurich. He has been principal and proprietor of Roland Gebhardt Design, located in downtown Manhattan, since 1987 and was the Designer Director for Robert P. Gersin Associates. He developed a line of sculptural furniture and holds several mechanical and design product patents.  He was the co-chair of Rebuild Downtown Our Town, and is a member of the steering committee for the Civic Alliance. Gebhardt is a faculty member of Pratt Institute, School of Architecture, Graduate Program for Urban Planning, and is a Fellow of The Institute for Urban Design. For more info visit www.RolandGebhardt.com.

TROPHIES features live music under the direction of Louis Nicolia of the Half Moon Consort.  Musicians include Andrija Andjelic (piano), Louis Nicolia (violin), Bradley T. Amidon (percussion), Rebecca Walsh (horns), James Pearson (cello), Sonny Froman (trimba — Moondog's unique percussion instrument).  Multiple Moondog compositions — including madrigals (vocal rounds), logrundes (instrumental works for ensemble), solo piano pieces and drum solos — will be performed without pauses; the trimba will lead the transitions between the different compositions.  TROPHIES is danced by Mercedes Searer, Macklin Kowal and Alexander Leslie Thompson. 

Mercedes Searer is a Brooklyn based dancer/choreographer and freelance arts administrator. Since arriving in New York in 2009 Mercedes has danced for Elizabeth Streb, Lucinda Childs, Deganit Shemy and Twyla Tharp, among others. She currently dances for Peter Kyle Dance and Jody Oberfelder.  Her choreography has been performed at the Andy Warhol Museum, The Children’s Museum, and Bellefield Hall, all in Pittsburgh, PA. Her work has also been featured in New York City at the Solar One Dance Series, Green Space’s Taking Root Series, Elm City Dance Series, and Triskelion’s Waxworks.

About Us

LakeArts Foundation is dedicated to bringing artists together to exchange information in workshops and symposia and to incubate new works through partnerships that nurture collaboration and ingenuity. This not only helps establish innovative relationships; it enables the foundation and our partners to share resources and offset today’s challenges of funding the arts.  It is extremely gratifying to witness the creation and development of exciting new projects that combine multiple disciplines and a wide range of talent.

The LakeArts Foundation, a not-for-profit organization founded in 2009, is committed to the development and presentation of global innovation in the arts and technology through the LakeArts Festival, the LakeArts Media Arts Programs, and the LakeArts Foundation Incubator.

For more information on the performance, please go to www.lakeartsfoundation.org, or call 716-451-4004.

What We Need & What You Get

We need a total of $15000 for this project and to help with marketing the next stop on the tour. Here is the breakdown:

  • $8000 for artists fees
  • $3000 for transportation and accommodations for the artists
  • $2000 for tech and artists materials
  • $2000 for marketing and administrative fees

In exchange for your support, we'll thank you with some one of-a-kind perks,  including

  • Sculptural masks signed by the artist
  • Signed copies of the book, Moondog: Viking of Sixth Avenue by Robert Scotto
  • Passes to our VIP reception, where you will be able to mingle with the artists

Why This Project is Important


Your support of this project allows us to bring together nine brilliant artists in a stunning performance that explores our humanity and showcases the effectiveness of the collaborative process. 

As a testament to the impact that TROPHIES has on the audience, we’d like to share two stories about our performances at the Erie Art Museum in Erie, PA, this past February. During one of the rehearsals, a group of schoolchildren who were on a tour of the museum stopped to watch our rehearsal of TROPHIES.  The students were mesmerized — held captive by its primal and playful magic.  In fact, they were so transfixed, the teacher had a hard time getting them back to the bus. 

In another rehearsal, a visiting diplomat from Ghana was so impressed by the piece, he asked to meet the artist, Roland Gebhardt, after a rehearsal. The diplomat remarked he was so used to seeing tribal masks hanging motionless on the walls of European and American museums, that he was elated that Roland's sculptural masks were imbued with life through dance and music.

As these stories illustrate, TROPHIES has the power to remind us of our common primal connection as human beings.  The collective effect of dance, music and masks in this TROPHIES performance reveals that art can be a powerful tool in making us more aware of who we are.


Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, there are still ways you can help:

  • Help us spread the word about our campaign by posting a link to our campaign on your social media sites and adding your enthusiastic comments
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
story_txt:
Thursday June 26th, 20145 pm and 6:30 pm
TROPHIES
featuring the masks of ROLAND GEBHARDTand the legendary music of MOONDOG performed by LOUIS NICOLIA and HALF MOON CONSORTchoreography by MERCEDES SEARER
JACK HANLEY GALLERY327 Broom Street New York, NYAdmission freeWhat happens when an international sculptor discovers a musician who preserves and performs the work of a legendary musician?
In the secluded community of Chautauqua, New York, at the LakeArts Foundation Incubator, such a thing happened — New York artist Roland Gebhardt met musician Louis Nicolia. The result is TROPHIES, an inspired collaboration, bringing together sculpture, modern dancers, and the music of Moondog.
With TROPHIES Gebhardt has created a provocative look at the art collector as hunter and art as a trophy to be pursued, captured and displayed on a wall.
Collecting trophies is a common social pursuit. Objects of perceived and real value are used as icons to express one's identity. Trophies are currency of social stature. In this performance piece, establishing and collecting hunting trophies serve as the analogy.
The music is by Moondog, a blind street musician who rose from the sidewalks of New York’s 6th Avenue to influence composers such as Phillip Glass, Peter Sellars, Steve Reich, Jon Gibson and Frank Zappa.
In TROPHIES it is dance and music that instill abstract masks with life. In this performance — second in an evolving international tour of varying iterations of the piece that introduces new dancers in each city — choreographer Mercedes Searer will join dancers Macklin Kowal and Alexander Leslie Thompson in an athletic, feral interpretation. The music of Moondog will be played by the Half Moon Consort chamber ensemble, founded by violinist Nicolia.
Nicolia’s Consort musicians are dedicated to furthering Moondog’s musical legacy. All are skilled performers of the music of "the Viking of Sixth Avenue” and have performed in numerous venues and cities, including Carnegie Hall.About the Artists

Roland Gebhardt is an internationally known sculptor and designer. In 2008 he debuted The Only Tribe, his first live theater piece for masks, which featured choreography by Peter Kyle and video design by Reid Farrington, at New York's 3LD Art & Technology Center. Best known for his monolithic sculptures, Gebhardt's work has been shown around the world and is in many prominent collections. He studied at both the Art Academy of Hamburg and the Kunstgewerbeschule in Zurich. He has been principal and proprietor of Roland Gebhardt Design, located in downtown Manhattan, since 1987 and was the Designer Director for Robert P. Gersin Associates. He developed a line of sculptural furniture and holds several mechanical and design product patents.  He was the co-chair of Rebuild Downtown Our Town, and is a member of the steering committee for the Civic Alliance. Gebhardt is a faculty member of Pratt Institute, School of Architecture, Graduate Program for Urban Planning, and is a Fellow of The Institute for Urban Design. For more info visit www.RolandGebhardt.com.

TROPHIES features live music under the direction of Louis Nicolia of the Half Moon Consort.  Musicians include Andrija Andjelic (piano), Louis Nicolia (violin), Bradley T. Amidon (percussion), Rebecca Walsh (horns), James Pearson (cello), Sonny Froman (trimba — Moondog's unique percussion instrument).  Multiple Moondog compositions — including madrigals (vocal rounds), logrundes (instrumental works for ensemble), solo piano pieces and drum solos — will be performed without pauses; the trimba will lead the transitions between the different compositions.  TROPHIES is danced by Mercedes Searer, Macklin Kowal and Alexander Leslie Thompson. Mercedes Searer is a Brooklyn based dancer/choreographer and freelance arts administrator. Since arriving in New York in 2009 Mercedes has danced for Elizabeth Streb, Lucinda Childs, Deganit Shemy and Twyla Tharp, among others. She currently dances for Peter Kyle Dance and Jody Oberfelder.  Her choreography has been performed at the Andy Warhol Museum, The Children’s Museum, and Bellefield Hall, all in Pittsburgh, PA. Her work has also been featured in New York City at the Solar One Dance Series, Green Space’s Taking Root Series, Elm City Dance Series, and Triskelion’s Waxworks.About UsLakeArts Foundation is dedicated to bringing artists together to exchange information in workshops and symposia and to incubate new works through partnerships that nurture collaboration and ingenuity. This not only helps establish innovative relationships; it enables the foundation and our partners to share resources and offset today’s challenges of funding the arts.  It is extremely gratifying to witness the creation and development of exciting new projects that combine multiple disciplines and a wide range of talent.The LakeArts Foundation, a not-for-profit organization founded in 2009, is committed to the development and presentation of global innovation in the arts and technology through the LakeArts Festival, the LakeArts Media Arts Programs, and the LakeArts Foundation Incubator.
For more information on the performance, please go to www.lakeartsfoundation.org, or call 716-451-4004.What We Need & What You GetWe need a total of $15000 for this project and to help with marketing the next stop on the tour. Here is the breakdown:
$8000 for artists fees

$3000 for transportation and accommodations for the artists

$2000 for tech and artists materials

$2000 for marketing and administrative fees
In exchange for your support, we'll thank you with some one of-a-kind perks,  including
Sculptural masks signed by the artist

Signed copies of the book, Moondog: Viking of Sixth Avenue by Robert Scotto
Passes to our VIP reception, where you will be able to mingle with the artists

Why This Project is ImportantYour support of this project allows us to bring together nine brilliant artists in a stunning performance that explores our humanity and showcases the effectiveness of the collaborative process. As a testament to the impact that TROPHIES has on the audience, we’d like to share two stories about our performances at the Erie Art Museum in Erie, PA, this past February. During one of the rehearsals, a group of schoolchildren who were on a tour of the museum stopped to watch our rehearsal of TROPHIES.  The students were mesmerized — held captive by its primal and playful magic.  In fact, they were so transfixed, the teacher had a hard time getting them back to the bus. In another rehearsal, a visiting diplomat from Ghana was so impressed by the piece, he asked to meet the artist, Roland Gebhardt, after a rehearsal. The diplomat remarked he was so used to seeing tribal masks hanging motionless on the walls of European and American museums, that he was elated that Roland's sculptural masks were imbued with life through dance and music.As these stories illustrate, TROPHIES has the power to remind us of our common primal connection as human beings.  The collective effect of dance, music and masks in this TROPHIES performance reveals that art can be a powerful tool in making us more aware of who we are.Other Ways You Can HelpEven if you can't contribute, there are still ways you can help:
Help us spread the word about our campaign by posting a link to our campaign on your social media sites and adding your enthusiastic comments
Use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
WHAT IT IS


I WANT THEM TO TURN BLACK...

Is a salon featuring performance art, photography, and new-media addressing standards of beauty, transformation, monstrosity, and the fragility of self- awareness. My name is RHYAN HAMILTON and I am a videographer in Brooklyn, New York. Moving to Manhattan at 18 years old, I always had a passion for the glamorous, the bizarre and the effects that vanity can have on a person.

In May I'll be graduating with a Bachelor's degree in Communications with a concentration in Creative Media from Marymount Manhattan College. For my Capstone Project I've chosen to produce a showcase of several artists' works which coincide with this theme of making art with one's body and exploring its limits.

The event, hosted by AMANDA LEPORE, is comprised of several installations, exhibitions and a performance. The main performance, starring LADY ALCHEMY, will be streamed live globally online on MAY 17TH, 2014 at iwantthemtoturnblack.com from COLONY STUDIOS in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. I have brought together some of the most amazing creatives this city has to offer. In order to reach my goal of producing and documenting the experience with a video of the main performance, I need the help of the community from which I've received enormous amounts of inspiration, acceptance, and encouragement.

#IWTB is a global platform for a conversation about the standards of beauty which an artist strives to transcend through sacrifice.


FOR MORE INFORMATION, VISIT IWANTTHEMTOTURNBLACK.COM


CHECK OUT THE FIRST OF THREE PROMOTIONAL VIDEOS RIGHT HERE!




            WHO IS INVOLVED?

                        

              

                       

              

 

         

                

                


                 DONATIONS

In order to fund the showcase, I'll need about $3,000 to fund production costs including sets, talent, props, installation materials, equipment rentals, promotional materials, catering, and transportation. 

I'm pleased to announce that we have several wonderful perks for all of our donators:

Various packages include Producer Status recognition, invitations to the private event, and much more! (All of the perks are named after artists, philosophers, writers, and other figures who have explored or exemplified the beautiful in the bizarre.)

Again, we are so thankful for all of your donations and for making this showcase happen!


  Here are ways you can help!

  • Spread the word! Share this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Tumblr, and any other social media.
  • Contribute your art! If you would like to be showcased in the event, send over any work you have relating to the theme here.
  • Be a part of the crew! Donate your valuable time and efforts to volunteering as one of the production crew on May 17th, 2014.

story:
Teresa Gómez-Martorell

  • I'm Teresa Gómez Martorell, artist printmaker and artist's books maker.
  • I am very proud for participating in one of the group portfolios shown in the Southern Graphics Conference which is a very important spot. It is a great opportunity to be there and spend time with amazing printmakers from all over the country and at the same time find artists to organize a future group portfolio.
  • I need to raise $1200 to cover my trip expenses for the conference. Southern Graphics will take place from March 26 to 29

What I Need & What You Get


  • For this purpose, I need the amount of 1200 dollars that covers the conference fee 450, a round trip to San Francisco $375 , hosting and food $400 . 
  • The advantage of having an artist friend is the possibility of enjoy art work. Hand made booklets made by the artist, self published books and prints will be offered in return to your support.
  • In case I do not reach my entire goal, no worries!  You still will get your print or book in exchange of your generosity. I'll be very happy with whatever funds I get from your generosity.
  • Please, get the word out and make noise about this campaign! What is important to me is important for you! 
  • And use Indiegogo tools!

story:
What is Mokuhanga?

Mokuhanga is the art technique of traditional Japanese woodblock. “Hanga” means printing and “moku” means wood. This art form became popular during the Edo period (1603-1867), where prints were made by publishing houses in Japan.

The publisher hired artists, carvers, and printers to create editions to sell to the public.  The 18th century genre Ukiyo-e, or “pictures of the floating world,” depicted images of everyday life: landscape, fashionable woman, actors, theatre, and other entertainment purposes. One of the most famous Japanese printmakers was Katsushika Hokusai during this era. His most famous work is titled Under the Wave off Kanagawa (The Great Wave).

Why I love Mokuhanga?

I first began printmaking in high school during a summer art program for gifted and talented students. Over 17 years I have practiced various forms art of printmaking such as relief, intaglio, silkscreen, collagraph, and lithography. I have recently taken four consecutive Mokuhanga classes with printmaker April Vollmer at The Lower Eastside Printshop.

When I was first introduced to Mokuhanga I fell in love with the application of water based ink applied to the wood surface. It’s flexibility of how the colors reacted to humid paper just by the amount of water, pressure, or pigment, is what makes this process so unique.

My rigorous study of printmaking has helped me to better understand how to transfer my ideas to any media I choose to work with. Now you too can own a work of art produced by me! I hope you can find the best place for my work to hang in your home or office.

Why I need your help?

It has always been a dream to me to study the art Japan abroad. I was recently selected out of over 100 international artists to present a paper presentation at the 2nd Annual International Mokuhanga Conference at The University of Tokyo. I will be one of the representatives of the United States of America to display my artistic skills and share my knowledge in the area of printmaking.

I need your help to make my dream a reality. With your support you will be able to contribute to my long awaited journey to Japan. I am interested in learning from master printers the technique and the origin of Mokuhanga in Japan to better understand how it has remained the same technically for over 300 years.

I hope to participate in traditional carving and paper making workshops that are taught by Japanese and international artists from around the world. During my trip I would like to observe the making of carving tools and barrens for printing.

This opportunity will not only provide technical knowledge but also the basis of educational foundation that I will use in my own teaching practice as an artist. I plan on using my experience to lecture, write publications, obtain artist residencies, and share the culture of Japan with my students.

What I Need to go Japan…

·  Help cover the cost of round trip airfare to Tokyo

·  Help pay for the cost of Hotel Accommodations

·  Transportation Costs: (airport, taxi, subway, etc.)

·  Food

·  Purchasing of personalized handmade tools and paper

·  Conference Registration

·  Personal Lesson with Master Japanese Printmaker

What are the Perks?:

Here is a closer look of what you can purchase to support my travel to Japan...

What to Do? -2014

Hot and Sizzle-2014

Saucy and Sweet-2014

Hot and Sizzle II-2014

Sparkling-2014



SPREAD THE WORD:

Help spread the word!  Even if you are not able to contribute financially, you can still help my dream come true. I am an artist and art educator that needs people like you to support me, so please use the Indiegogo "Share Tools" to spread the word about my I Love Mokuhanga Campaign! Thank you for taking the time to visit my vision, any and all contributions will be gratefully received!

SHARE THE CAMPAIGN

http://www.igg.me/at/ilovemokuhangamack

story:
My Story

The Impact

I am a self-trained artist who is inspired by the beauty of nature and the guiding force of my intuition. I draw and I create primal sculpture and wearable art from trees and stones, which I fashion into ritual staffs, wearable amulets, and employ in healing rituals. My designs are entirely hand-made and one-of-a-kind.

 

British Airways recently announced that my business “Sticks & Stones” has been selected as a 2010 Face-of-Opportunity winner and has been awarded travel to anywhere in the world to conduct business meetings, as well as attend the British Airways Face-of-Opportunity business conference. This award is part of the British Airways Face-to-Face program, which provides small business owners and entrepreneurs the critical tools for building business relationships abroad and stimulating growth through the power of face- to-face interaction.

 

Sounds great, right? But … British Airways supplies only the plane tickets.  In order for me to take advantage of this amazing opportunity, I have to raise the money for all my living expenses once overseas.  Also, because of the contest rules, I must travel from February 3rd and return by March 4th.  In other words, I have to raise money fast!

 

I plan to travel to Thailand, a relatively low-cost destination with a centuries-old tradition of woodcarving, in order to meet and study with indigenous master wood carvers and native shaman.  My goal is to increase my technical proficiency, deepen my work as a healing ritual artist -- and document the experience on video. I will also learn about international commerce from the British Airways sessions, make global connections with the other contest winners, and explore ways to exhibit my work overseas. 

 

I have connected with like-minded volunteers in Bangkok who will act as my tour guides for several weeks during my stay. They will travel with me to Chaing Main and more remote areas, provide part-time housing, introduce me to artists and shamans, and help me document my work.

 

In a nutshell: I want to travel to Thailand to deepen my art-making by connecting with people who employ ritual objects for healing and spiritual purposes.   I see myself uniquely positioned in the crossroads between ritual and art – and as a conduit from ancient ways to modern times. I’ve touched upon something via my artwork that feels very important, not only to me, but potentially to others as well.  I hope as I continue to develop, I can offer what I discover to a wider and wider circle of people.

 

Want to read more? 

 

What I Need & What You Get

Some history:

Due to a life-threatening crisis in 2002, I spontaneously started carving for protection and spiritual connection – making what I call “Sacred Staffs” from the roots and trunks of trees.  Prior to becoming a visual artist, I was an actor, employing the ritual aspects of theatre to impact community.  Now my path to a sacred space and a quest towards the divine has shifted to creating sacred objects and drawings. My work explores issues of love and loss, spirituality, sexuality, and gender identification and how these intersect.  I also teach workshops combing these elements. Through these various ritual practices and explorations, I’ve been fortunate to obtain a glimpse of my healing abilities.

 

I tapped into carving on a visceral level, and what stemmed from crisis evolved to exhibition: The Prospect Park Alliance and the Audubon Center sponsored a three-month solo show “Sticks & Stones” at the Boathouse in Brooklyn’s Prospect Park, and The National Museum of Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual & Transgender History presented a two-month solo show.  I was profiled in The Daily News; was the subject of feature articles in Mann About Town magazine, Home News Tribune, In Brooklyn, The Park Slope Paper, The Wave, and The Daily Sitka Sentinel, and featured on NY-1 Television.

 

In 2009, I was awarded a Development Grant from Fractured Atlas to study with Native American Tlingit master woodcarver Tommy Joseph in Sitka Alaska. I worked with Tommy in his beautiful studio at the Southeast Indian Cultural Center, housed inside the Sitka National Historical Park. I was surrounded by formline art – a style rarely seen in New York City outside of the Museum of the American Indian. When I stepped into Tommy’s studio I was overwhelmed by the sheer beauty and power of the objects within. Under Tommy’s tutelage, I carved a mask out of a tree trunk using traditional Tlingit hand tools. The mask, entitled “Trans-Formation” manifested from a dream. Carving with Tommy was hard physical work, humbling, profound – and lots of fun too. (See “The Spirit in the Mask” http://artistsoulspeaks.wordpress.com/2009/10/1....

 

Carvings, and the creation of masks and staffs, are an ancient art form of expression in many cultures and traditions, including in Judaism, my roots.  And in the past most designed objects were used for ritual. But I live in NYC -- a fast-paced environment surrounded by mass-produced goods created by machines. The objects most of us use on a daily basis have little intrinsic beauty or spiritual value. And all too often we live separated from nature and many of us rarely participate in rituals, rites of passage or celebrations with community.

 

 

Thailand is well known for the carving of statues destined for various Buddhist temples in Thailand and other parts of Asia. Bangkok has countless examples of this type of carving, with its pinnacle being the reclining Buddha at Wat Pho, the longest reclining Buddha in the world. Wat Pho also contains over 1,000 other Buddha images, many carved. Secular carving is also popular and can include carvings of monkeys, elephants or other natural forms. There is a parallel history of Animism with a belief that guardian spirits inhabit rivers, canals, trees and other natural features, which pre-dates the arrival of all other religions and still plays a role in the everyday life of most residents, with spirit shrines in abundance throughout the country. 

 

 

Studying with Native carver Tommy Joseph in Alaska inspired me, and now I want to build on that experience to work with artists who have a different form of Native art, integral and essential to their lives. I am fascinated to meet and study with Thai masters, to expose myself to their ancient forms and incorporate them into my work in a non-traditional environment: the urban jungle that is New York.  My goal is to continue my study with artists who recognize the vital connection between the Source, the earth, what we make with our hands, and our global connection to one-another.

 

Now, via this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity offered from British Airways, along with your contribution, I will be able to enhance my proficiency and deepen the inherent spiritual connection of my artwork.  I look forward to my return and to sharing with you what I learn. 

Will you help me to actualize my gifts so that they can be a source of beauty, healing, and joy?

I plan to stay in the cheapest (safe) accommodations, stay with my tour guides and other local families and in backpacking hostels whenever possible. Still, I need money for transportation, lodging, food, immunization shots, equipment  – plus money for materials and to donate to my teachers. I’ve been advised that I should have approximately $3,000 for the trip, which, G-d willing, will take place February 3rd – March 3rd 2011. 


I already have the plane reservations – but I can’t get on the plane and go to Thailand without your help! 

 

My fundraising goals:

40 people donate $10 ($400)

35 donate $20 ($700)

25 donate $30 ($750)

15 donate $40 (600)

5 donate $50 ($250)

3 donate $100 ($300)

Total goal: $3,000

NOTE:  If I reach my goal, website administrators take 9% if I don’t meet my goal, and 4% if I do.

 

If I don’t raise at least $1,000 by February 1st – I won’t step foot on the plane! Of course you have ‘till March 2nd to make your donations … but please don’t wait that long – do it right away!

 

Will you support me at the highest level that is comfortable for you?

 

Any amount will help me reach my goal. 

 

Safe and secure on-line donations can be made right on this site.

 

MANY THANKS IN ADVANCE!

 

Other Ways You Can Help


Please share this campaign via Facebook, Twitter and email – see the tools on this site. Please talk about my campaign to your friends and forward this link.


Extend your support to artists in Thailand! 

(Please see “Perks.”)
story_txt:
My Story








The Impact






I am a self-trained artist who is inspired by the beauty of nature and the
guiding force of my intuition. I draw and I create
primal sculpture and wearable art from trees and stones, which I fashion into
ritual staffs, wearable amulets, and employ in healing rituals. My designs are
entirely hand-made and one-of-a-kind. 
 
British
Airways recently announced that my business “Sticks & Stones” has been
selected as a 2010 Face-of-Opportunity winner and has been awarded travel to
anywhere in the world to conduct business meetings, as well as attend the British Airways
Face-of-Opportunity business conference. This award is part of the British Airways Face-to-Face program, which provides
small business owners and entrepreneurs the critical tools for building
business relationships abroad and stimulating growth through the power of face- to-face interaction. 
 
Sounds great, right? But … British Airways
supplies only the plane tickets.  In order for me to take advantage of
this amazing opportunity, I have to raise the money for all my living expenses
once overseas.  Also, because of the contest rules, I must travel from
February 3rd and return by March 4th.  In other words, I have to raise money fast!
 
I plan to travel to Thailand, a relatively low-cost destination with a centuries-old tradition
of woodcarving, in order to meet and
study with indigenous master wood carvers and native shaman.  My goal is to increase my technical
proficiency, deepen my work as a healing ritual artist -- and document the
experience on video. I will also learn about international commerce from the
British Airways sessions, make global connections with the other contest
winners, and explore ways to exhibit my work overseas.  
 
I have connected
with like-minded volunteers in Bangkok who will act as my tour guides for several
weeks during my stay. They will travel with me to Chaing Main and more remote
areas, provide part-time housing, introduce me to artists and shamans, and help
me document my work. 
 
In a nutshell: I want to
travel to Thailand to deepen my art-making by connecting with people who employ
ritual objects for healing and spiritual purposes.   I see myself uniquely positioned in the crossroads
between ritual and art – and as a conduit from ancient ways to modern times.
I’ve touched upon something via my artwork that feels very important, not only
to me, but potentially to others as well. 
I hope as I continue to develop, I can offer what I discover to a wider
and wider circle of people. 
 
Want to read more?  
 



What I Need & What You Get






Some history: 
Due to a life-threatening crisis in 2002, I spontaneously
started carving for protection and spiritual connection – making what I call
“Sacred Staffs” from the roots and trunks of trees.  Prior to becoming a
visual artist, I was an actor, employing the ritual aspects of theatre to
impact community.  Now my path to a
sacred space and a quest towards the divine has shifted to creating sacred
objects and drawings. My work explores issues of love and loss, spirituality,
sexuality, and gender identification and how these intersect.  I also teach workshops combing these
elements. Through these various ritual practices and explorations, I’ve been
fortunate to obtain a glimpse of my healing abilities. 
 
I tapped into carving on a visceral level, and what
stemmed from crisis evolved to exhibition: The Prospect Park
Alliance and the Audubon Center sponsored a three-month solo show “Sticks &
Stones” at the Boathouse in Brooklyn’s Prospect Park, and The National Museum of Lesbian, Gay, Bisexual
& Transgender History presented a two-month solo show.  I was profiled in The Daily News; was the subject of feature articles in Mann About Town magazine, Home News Tribune, In Brooklyn, The Park Slope
Paper, The Wave, and The Daily Sitka Sentinel, and featured on NY-1 Television.
 
In 2009, I was awarded a Development Grant from Fractured
Atlas to study with Native American Tlingit master woodcarver Tommy Joseph in
Sitka Alaska. I worked with Tommy in his beautiful
studio at the Southeast Indian Cultural
Center, housed inside the Sitka National Historical Park. I was surrounded by
formline art – a style rarely seen in New York City outside of the Museum of
the American Indian. When I stepped into Tommy’s studio I was overwhelmed by
the sheer beauty and power of the objects within. Under Tommy’s tutelage, I carved a mask out of a tree trunk using traditional Tlingit hand
tools. The mask, entitled “Trans-Formation” manifested from a dream. Carving
with Tommy was hard physical work, humbling, profound – and lots of fun too.
(See “The Spirit in the Mask” http://artistsoulspeaks.wordpress.com/2009/10/1....

 
Carvings, and the creation of masks and staffs,
are an ancient art form of expression in many cultures and traditions,
including in Judaism, my roots.  And in the past most designed objects were used
for ritual. But
I live in NYC -- a fast-paced environment surrounded by
mass-produced goods created by machines. The objects most of us use on a daily
basis have little intrinsic beauty or spiritual value. And all too often we
live separated from nature and many of us rarely participate in rituals, rites
of passage or celebrations with community.
 
 
Thailand is well known for the carving of statues
destined for various Buddhist temples in Thailand and other parts of Asia.
Bangkok has countless examples of this type of carving, with its pinnacle being
the reclining Buddha at Wat Pho, the longest reclining Buddha in the world. Wat
Pho also contains over 1,000 other Buddha images, many carved. Secular carving
is also popular and can include carvings of monkeys, elephants or other natural
forms. There is a parallel history of Animism with a belief that guardian
spirits inhabit rivers, canals, trees and other natural features, which
pre-dates the arrival of all other religions and still plays a role in the
everyday life of most residents, with spirit shrines in abundance throughout the
country.  
 
 
Studying with Native carver Tommy
Joseph in Alaska inspired me, and now I want to build on that experience to
work with artists who have a different form of Native art, integral and
essential to their lives. I am fascinated to meet and study with Thai masters,
to expose myself to their ancient forms and incorporate them into my work in a
non-traditional environment: the urban jungle that is New York.  My goal is to continue my study with
artists who recognize the vital connection between the Source, the earth, what
we make with our hands, and our global connection to one-another. 
 
Now, via this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity offered from
British Airways, along with your contribution, I will be able to enhance my
proficiency and deepen the inherent spiritual connection of my artwork.  I look forward to my return and to
sharing with you what I learn.  


Will you help me to actualize my gifts so that they
can be a source of beauty, healing, and joy?


I plan to stay in the cheapest (safe)
accommodations, stay with my tour guides and other local families and in
backpacking hostels whenever possible. Still, I need money for transportation,
lodging, food, immunization shots, equipment  – plus money for materials and to donate to my teachers.
I’ve been advised that I should have approximately $3,000 for the trip, which, G-d willing, will take place February 3rd
– March 3rd 2011. 



I already have the plane reservations – but I can’t get
on the plane and go to Thailand without your help!  
 
My fundraising goals:
40 people donate $10 ($400)
35 donate $20 ($700)
25 donate $30 ($750)
15 donate $40 (600)
5 donate $50 ($250)
3 donate $100 ($300)
Total goal: $3,000
NOTE:  If I reach my goal, website administrators take 9% if I
don’t meet my goal, and 4% if I do.
 
If I don’t raise at least
$1,000 by February 1st – I won’t step foot on the plane! Of course you have ‘till March 2nd to make your
donations … but please don’t wait that long – do it right away!
 
Will you support me at the highest level that is
comfortable for you?
 
Any amount will help me reach my
goal.  
 
Safe and secure on-line donations can be made right on this site. 
 
MANY THANKS IN ADVANCE!
 
Other Ways You Can Help



Please share this campaign via Facebook, Twitter and
email – see the tools on this site. Please talk about my campaign to your friends
and forward this link. 


Extend your support to artists in Thailand!  
(Please see “Perks.”)

story:
3... 2... 1... SHOW THE LOVE!

My name is Inali (Merissa) Barger and this year I qualified to be on the London Poetry Slam Team alongside Ted Olczak, Melissa Krone, Matthew Dryden, and Ben McCabe. 

Among other things, this means that we get to represent London, Ontario on a National level against 20+ other teams across Canada at the Canadian Festival of Spoken Word (CFSW). This festival is an amazing experience consisting not only of the National title competition, but of workshops, showcases, and additional competitions that happen over a week.

The catch is, we can only go if we can afford it. This year, CFSW is being hosted in Saskatoon, Saskatchewan-- which means it's a bit of a hike for those of us on the London Team. That's why we need your help!

What We Need & What You Get

What we need:

Plane Tickets
Accomodations

What you get:

Ok, so you don't want to just hand over some cash-- I understand! We have a lot to offer in return for your generous support.

CDs
Dogtags
T-Shirts
Performances
Workshops
Shout Outs
Personalized Poems


 

The Impact

Spoken word has impacted my life on many levels. As an individual, it has increased my self-awareness, world awareness, public speaking abilities, and has empowered me to use my voice to advocate for myself and others. In general, I've watched it bring together creative and talented people as a strong collective effort that is having a growing impact on our community. 

Opportunities like CFSW allow for the growth and strengthening of the resources that are developing from this collective effort, such as workshops in schools, fundraising for local organizations, and reminding people of the power and potential impact of using their voice.

At the London Slam our mottos are "Speak Your Truth" and "Show the Love", two phrases that encourage honest expression, the advocacy for self and others, and a strong sense of positive leadership by example.

These qualities are valuable not only to our community, but in any social setting, and we would be honoured to have the opportunity to share that message once again with this year's team on a National Stage. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Donating money is not the only way you can help. Spreading the word that we are in need of aid via facebook, twitter, clicking share on indiegogo, word of mouth-- any way you can think of-- would be of great assistance!

We truly appreciate all of your support!

story:
4.2.13:  Wow! So so so close! 28 hours and $18 to go!  Thanks to the 31 folks who have supported me so far.  If we hit the goal, it will cover a good share of the costs of this adventure.  If we surpass, it will help me a little more.  Either way: THANK YOU for purchasing one of these special bundles, whose funds will go to a very special adventure.

love,

J

_________________________________________________

Recently my pal Karen, expert in massage, accordion, and kindness, shared words from a letter she’d written to herself in a class years ago, as part of a class assignment:

“dream big, big dreamer, and ask for help if you want it”

One of my goals this year is MORE MAGIC. I've concocted a little scheme that fits that goal--but it’s a little complicated, logistically.  But I can't stop thinking it's possible....After seeing Karen's words I thought, why not ask for help to make this happen? 

It's bizarre how hard it can be to ask for help.  People like helping, so why are so many of us afraid to ask?  So here I am, asking for your help!

As a result of my moveto a massive, urban, far-away place, as my husband begins a new career, I've had to really think about my goals and priorities over the last year, and as a result I've more firmly committed to growing and pushing my creative work, and how I communicate this process. This campaign is another step in that direction!

OVERVIEW:

My dream is to attend a week-long artist workshop with the inspirational artist Jill Bliss this August, on the Cortes Islands off of Vancouver.

Technically speaking, Vancouver is on the way home from Shanghai,
and late summer is about the time I hope to make my next trip home:

{Shanghai - - - -> Vancouver - - - > Minneapolis}

So--actually--actually it’s a VERY PRACTICAL plan...but I'd love your help with the logistics.

I’m offering you some special packages of goodness that will help fund this dream. Your purchase will boost my travel fund but also let you be part of the experience through one-time-only works of art, artful letters, and reports from the field that will be made from the experience. 

Help me make magic happen.

The goal amount will cover some, but not all, of my costs.  If we meet the goal--awesome. If we surpass it, super awesome!  Either way it's a win-win!

 

WHAT YOU’LL GET!
You can jump on this dream-train by buying a special package that is part of my effort to fund this trip. And of course in supporting me you’ll by extension support Jill’s work as an artist, too!

UPDATE 3/13: EVERYONE who participates will get in on the "secret email club"


(ALTERNATIVELY:)
Make any purchase in my etsy shop and you’ll also be a great support to me and my artistic dreams.


I REALLY REALLY THANK YOU:
THANK YOU!  thank  you! THANK YOU! thank you!

AND: You know, you know you know I will pay it forward, share what I've learned and help others in a similar position going forward.

 

BACKSTORY:
Jill Bliss is an artist I’ve admired and followed for years. Her artistic practice includes observation of the natural world and its intricate patterns made into artwork and everyday objects. She makes prints and paintings, but she also creates reproducable practical objects such as journals and planners, with gorgeous detailed drawings and layers.
     
I’ve been following her instagram feed lately, while she is on a sabbatical year in an amazing natural setting. I’ve been droooooling over the gorgeous imagery she posts. 

One day I thought: what would it be like if I dropped myself from Shanghai into that setting? What would it do to my brain and how would it startle my creative workings?
     
And THEN--a few weeks later, I got a note from Jill with a special heads-up for people on her mailing list about a workshop she’s leading, in those very islands, immersed in nature and daily drawing and guidance. I immediately said to myself, “I MUST GO.”
And I’m still saying it. I cannot stop saying it.


GOALS:
My goal is to be delivered to this setting that is so opposite of Shanghai and see what happens, see what kind of jolt it gives my body, mind, and spirit.  I want to spend a week honing my drawing and observational skills in an unreal setting, and gulping up fresh air.

I’m also going with two additional intentions:

1.  that this workshop will help me learn from Jill’s example and working style, and work habits she’s developed over her career and while on sabbatical

2. that I will begin to unfold a visual narrative/children’s book that is brewing inside my head


P.S. Check the "updates" tab now and then, where I'll be posting fun thank you notes and more about my goals for this workshop.
